column180: Agreement,Amendment 2 to Agreement,Decision,Decision on Amendment of Contribution,Decision
column200: This statement concerns the Annual Narrative Report of the intervention Livelihoods Improvement for Women and Youth (LI-WAY). The reporting period for this statement is January 2020 to December 2020 and was delivered on time according to the LI-WAY grant agreement.During the reporting period (January to December 2020)\, LI-WAY made significant progress despite the prevalence of COVID 19 pandemic and the subsequent measures taken by the federal government and Addis Ababa city administration that curtail implementation of planned interventions. Sector teams and implementing partners adapted to the situation and continued delivering\, including designing a short-term response plan to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on our target groups and protecting previous program investments.As a result\, though the plan was to create nearly 16\,000 jobs during the reporting period\, LI-WAY managed to create 1\,150 jobs\, all from the MSEs and Skills sector\, achieving 7% against the annual target. Percentage achievement is expected to increase in the second half of the year\, given an improvement in the COVID 19 pandemic situation and opening up of the economy. Labor and Growth sector performances has also need to improve in the next reporting period. In the reporting period\, competent implementing partners developed and submitted a technical proposal to test scalable and sustainable business models that are believed to be instrumental to address key market constraints and thereby improving the employability of women and youth for increased income. Therefore\, LI-WAY co-created ten concept notes and secured approval for implementation.Similarly\, 45 enterprises established and demonstrated improved business performance. Improved business performance is characterized by increase in sales\, creating employment opportunity to our target groups\, access to finance and established business relations with customers.  LI-WAY achieved 102% of the target for the year in the reporting period.   As a response to COVID-19 pandemic\, the LI-WAY team quickly worked to adapt their strategy; conducting a rapid assessments of the impact of the pandemic on target groups and preparing response plans. LI-WAY facilitated a training for 290 unemployed women and youth on disinfection and cleaning services and created temporary jobs for 172 of them. Further\, LI-WAY provided emergency direct supports (such as cash for first month\, sanitation materials like face mask\, sanitizer etc.) to cover house rent and food for 1\,643 of the target group\, to support them to cope with the effects of COVID-19 at least for two months. Specific highlights/challenges per sector: 1.  Labor sector\, 2.  Growth Sector\,  3. MSM Enterprise\, and Skills sector\, 1. The Labour SectorThe labour team was not able to pursue the implementation of planned activities in 2020 due to government restrictions to following COVID-19. Consequently\, the planned 2020 annual targets for interventions in the labour sector have a completion rate of less than 2.5 %.Two interventions were designed and implemented to respond to the challenges posed by COVID-19\, namely Direct Support and Temporary Job Creation through Disinfection and Cleaning Services.Cash transfer and sanitation materials were distributed for 650 women through Direct Support. This support helped the target groups to cover costs of living & accommodation (house rent) and protect themselves and their household members from the pandemic. Some beneficiaries used the money to start trades like the sale of used cloths\, face masks\, sanitizer\, and alcohol in local markets and public streets for profit. LI-WAY facilitated training on disinfection for 447 (234 women) domestic workers who were laid off from their work due to the outbreak of the COVID-19 to provide disinfection and cleaning services. A total of 287 (150 women) workers were deployed and earned more than 1.3 million ETB (270\,492 SEK) as an income to support their household living. They disinfected and cleaned a total of 450\,000 m2 in 124 businesses and also enabled private businesses and government organisations to continue their operation and maintain their employees. There are plans to continue this intervention and scale up to 2000 beneficiaries.The Digital Job Matching (DJM) services intervention has been postponed due to a change of implementing partner due to inability of the partner to implement the intervention. The Labour Sector team has now identified MinabTech to pursue the DJM intervention with. The new agreement will be finalized in the next reporting period.2. The Growth SectorDue to COVID-19\, the growth team has had to postpone the implementation of many planned activities in 2020. As a consequence\, the team has not been able to deliver on the result targets for 2020\, and cumulative results for LI-WAY were at a completion rate of less than 2 %. The majority of activities for intervention under the growth sector remain at a stage where the Growth Sector team prepares for implementation. Low completion rate of targets suggests a need to review programme results targets under the growth sector to ensure that the set targets for the programme are achievable.The pandemic has limited research by limiting the teams ability to conduct an impact evaluation\, which was originally planned for this reporting period. The Growth Sector team has postponed the formal impact evaluation until pandemic-related restrictions are lifted.No market/partner capital mobilisation has been reported during the reporting period\, however\, no analysis/commentary has been provided regarding challenges to mobilise private capital. This will be an interesting point to analyse in both the upcoming Mid-Term Review and Impact Evaluation.The Growth Sector team cancelled the agreement with the implementing partner for the Worke Cart intervention. The reason for the cancellation was the lack of progress made by the implementing partner. The new intervention business model has been designed to incorporate more than two market actors to support faster intervention implementation. A new partnership agreement has been signed and 1\,250 women and youth are expected to benefit from this intervention during the lifetime of the program. That would entail that the current final target of 3807 beneficiaries must be revised. Implementation of the intervention is reported to start in Q1 2021. 3.  The Micro and Small  Enterprises Sector (MSE) The MSE sector of LI-WAY is progressing relatively better than other sectors of the programme. Nevertheless\, the annual reports that COVID-19 has negatively affected the operation\, performance\, and growth of the MSE sector for the LI-WAY target groups. Only a few annual targets could be met in 2020 and the program´s lifetime targets are trailing behind. The report\, however\, does not provide any analysis of whether the final result targets are achievable within the remaining time LI-WAY. Self-employment in existing enterprises outperformed the targets for 2020\, achieving 141% of the annual target and 82% of the LOI target. Accordingly\, 2\,089 target women and youth have increased their income through sales during the reporting period. Self-employment in new enterprises was also successful in supporting the creation of self-employment for women and youth with 387 women and youth becoming self-employed during the reporting period (103 % of annual target). It would be relevant to analyse key factors of this success of the self-employment interventions to provide learning for the LI-WAY programme. The Digital Marketing Service (DMS) for micro-enterprises intervention improved the performance of 740 established women and youth-owned enterprises\, achieving 49% of the annual target and 37% of the life of the Intervention (LoI) target. Key lessons learned from DMS. While implementing the intervention the MSM team found that they: (1) should target women and youth with the capacity (e.g. resource)\, information and entrepreneurial skills were able to adapt and respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. These beneficiaries proactively repurposed their businesses to produce the most needed items and respond to emerging demands\, continue their business\, and earn income. They also found that (2) trust is a major obstacle for e-commerce. This obstacle is also made harder for MEs as many are unable to produce receipts of purchases to customers. The annual report highlights that there is a need to increase awareness and enforcing rules and regulations together with relevant government offices to support the inclusiveness of e-commerce.4. The Skills Development Sector1775 jobs were created during the reporting period\, achieving 25% of the target for the year (3079). To date\, the sector created jobs and improved monthly income of 1\,741 LI-WAY targets (871 young and adult women\, 870 young men) accounting for 4% achievement against the Life of the Program (LOP) target of 41\,000. Interventions have been more successful in creating self-employment (1\,553\, or 89% total) than wage-employment (188\, or 11% of total). These outputs are similar to those seen under the MSM sector and should be analysed further to better understand the dynamics of the labour market. The Skills Development sector mobilised ETB 3\,032\,875 from partners to implement pilot interventions and achieved 89% of the plan for the year\, which was ETB 3\,425\,750. The sector managed to generate and invest ETB 7\,393\,400 to date\, attaining 62% of the LOP target of ETB 12\,000\,000. It would be beneficial to analyse what made the skills development sector successful in mobilising capital from partners\, as other LI-WAY sectors have struggled to mobilise capital. The sector team conducted a portfolio review together with Agora Global. The review was aimed at assessing progress within the sector framework and guide the direction to achieve results and ensure sustainability and scale-up in line with the MSD approach. One key recommendation was to highlight the need to update the sector strategy document. The Product Design & Development Skills Outsourcing Scheme for MEs intervention has been delayed as the Akaki-kaliti polytechnic college has terminated the partnership with Skyline. This occurred as Skyline wanted to implement the intervention directly by themselves\, which is against the principles of the MSD approach. The lead partner\, Akaki-kaliti polytechnic college\, is looking for other options including partnering with another TVET college.__________________________________________________________________Results for 2021 reflect a leap forward after a long start-up period of five years: Overall\, the report reflects that LIWAY is innovative\, well-managed\, progressing well and adaptive to historic challenges encountered particularly since 2020.  LIWAYs Annual Report displays a thoughtful and frank analysis of challenges\, risks\, and corrective actions taken. Following the mid-term review\, it is appropriate to reassess what has been achieved and learned and what opportunities there are for further adaptation and improvements using the MSD approach.  Overall\, LIWAY reports impressive results in terms of the target beneficiaries as a result of 45 live and completed interventions:26\,277 beneficiaries with improved incomes 19\,159 new jobs created 239 new MSEs created 7\,345 enterprises with an improved business model 60 intervention partnerships Over 259 Million ETB partnership resources leveragedNotably\, these are immediate outputs\, and measures of improved income are not reported with a focus on significant increases.Within the systems change approach used by LIWAY\, the overall results reported by LIWAY indicates that major results were driven by skills system followed by MSE results.The skills system has over performed nearly all targets (notably except for young men and adult women in terms of increased income through wage employment):The skills system is leading with facilitating employment and income opportunities for a total of 15\,081 women and youth (57%) followed by the MSE system with 8\,189 beneficiaries (31%) of the results to date. The MLE system is lagging in achieving employment and income for target groups\, having benefitted only 1\,308 (5%) poor people to date\, followed by the labour system with only 1\,699 (6%)\, although there are signs of system change that could result in better scale in the labour system. [p. 12]Challenges and Key Learnings.  LIWAY has identified four major challenges encountered including GoE agency restructuring\, limited understanding of market systems approach\, COVID-19\, and partner operational issues.  Each of these has been adaptively addressed.  Key learnings identified include new strategies for identifying and working with partners (including early follow up)\, adaptive COVID-19 responses and working to get government officials to observe and develop buy-in on new approaches to economic development and effective interventions.  All of the responses seem excellent.
column219: No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

column17: Justice for all 2017-2020\, An Integrated Project for Human Rights Protection...,Justice for all 2017-2021
column20:
Etiopien har registrerat ett antal ekonomiska milstolpar och landvinningar och har tagit anmärkningsvärda steg när det gäller skydd av mänskliga rättigheter i form av lagstiftning snarare än fullständigt genomförande.Studier och undersökningar visar att det i Etiopien finns avsevärda luckor i att uppfylla de mänskliga rättigheternas skyldigheter och ta sig olika former\, till exempel behandling av fångar i fängelser/fängelser som är långt ifrån de internationella minimistandardreglerna och praxis. Andra former av kränkning inkluderar godtyckliga arresteringar\, förlängt frihetsberövande före spår och interneringscenter. En del av dessa svagheter förvärras av en utbredd brist på medvetenhet om mänskliga rättigheter från de brottsbekämpande organen och bristande engagemang för att iaktta sina skyldigheter för mänskliga rättigheter och förekomsten av rättsstatsprincipen.Insatsen omfattar aktiviteter för att stärka kapaciteten hos de lagstiftande\, verkställande och rättsliga organen utöver opinionsbildning\, forskning\, erfarenhetsutbyte och lobbying för förbättrad politik\, lagstiftning och institutionell miljö och ökade människorättsvänliga åtalssystem. Projektet föreslår partnerskap med ett brett spektrum av aktörer som sträcker sig från statliga institutioner till media och civilsamhällesgrupper. Ett nära samarbete med regeringen kommer att vara nödvändigt för att uppnå önskade förändringar. Samtidigt pekar förslaget på många utmaningar som snabb personalomsättning\, brist på offentliga resurser\, maktfrågor\, bristande politisk vilja och institutionell konservatism. Slutsatsen är att organisationen har visat tillräckligt med kapacitet och kompetens att fortsätta drivkraften i sina resultat inom rättsväsendet.,Ethiopia has registered a number of economic milestones and achievements and has made remarkable steps with respect to human rights protection in terms of legislation rather than full implementation.

Studies and surveys show that in Ethiopia\, there are considerable gaps in fulfilling the human rights obligations and take different forms\, such us treatment of detainees in prison/detention centers which is far from the international minimum standard rules and practices. Other forms of violation includes arbitrary arrest\, prolonged pre-trail detention and detention centers. Some of those weaknesses are exacerbated by widespread lack of human rights awareness by the law enforcement bodies and lack of commitment to observe their human rights obligations and prevalence of rule of law.

The intervention entails activities on enhancing capacity of the legislative\, executive and judiciary bodies in addition to advocacy works\, researches\, experience sharing and lobbying for improved policy\, legislative and institutional environment and increased human rights friendly prosecution systems. The project proposes partnerships with a wide range of actors spanning from government institutions to media and civil society groups. Working closely with the government will be necessary in order to achieve the desired changes. At the same time the proposal points out many challenges such as rapid turnover of staff\, scarcity of public resources\, power issues\, lack of political will and institutional conservatism.
The conclusion is that the organization has demonstrated enough capacity and expertise to continue the momentum of their results in the Justice sector.,The overall objective of this project is to contribute to the enhancement of status of human rights\, good governance\, peace and the rule of law.
There is no major change in the objective of the project; however\, a rather specific objective has been added. Even thought the target group remains the same\, there is an additional objective of enhancing the role of the target group (law enforcement organs) in undertaking a free\, fair preaceful election and a people controlled democracy and transition in Ethiopia.
column27: Sweden,JFA-PFE/Justice For All - Prison Fellowship Ethiopia,Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency,JFA-PFE/Justice For All - Prison Fellowship Ethiopia
column91: 10.2 - By 2030\, empower and promote the social\, economic and political inclusion of all\, irrespective of age\, sex\, disability\, race\, ethnicity\, origin\, religion or economic or other status.,10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors\, oavsett ålder\, kön\, funktionsnedsättning\, ras\, etnicitet\, ursprung\, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning\, blir inkluderade i det sociala\, ekonomiska och politiska livet.,10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome\, including by eliminating discriminatory laws\, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation\, policies and action in this regard.,10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall\, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning\, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning\, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.,16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter\, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.,16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms\, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.,16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.,16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.,16.6 - Develop effective\, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.,16.7 - Ensure responsive\, inclusive\, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.,16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört\, inkluderande\, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.,16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.,16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.,5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt,5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres\, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet\, inklusive människohandel\, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.,5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer,5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column200: Overall the cooperation partner has successfully implemented the project even if thetheory of change was very ambitious. The ambition and the project's relativecontribution to the "Improved status of human rights\, good governance\, peace and ruleof law in Ethiopia" could be said that is quite small. However\, the cooperation partnerdid its level best to position the implementation of the program at the very heart of thereform plans of relevant institutions of the judiciary that have been targeted. In doing so\,the final evaluation has found the program to have had\, among many others:1. dramatic (positive) change in terms of use of force and human rights abuses allegationsfrom militia and regional police forces2. Significant improvement in the behavior of police and militia towards unlawful arrestand excessive use of force3. astonishing case clearance rates in regional and federal courts4. expansion of the restorative justice initiative that was started in a handful of woredas inAmhara and Oromia to many more woredas. It is worth remembering that thatrestorative justice and the transitional justice are somewhat similar and JFA-PFE willhopefully play a constructive role in Ethiopia's effort to set up a transitional justiceframework.The cooperation partner has had to adapt to changing context\, most notably due tochanging political context in the early 2018\, COVID-19 in 2020 and the escalation offull fledged war in the past two years. As stated above\, JFA-PFE was in a position tosupport most relevant institutions for their reforms after the new government was put inplace in 2018 and this led to the revision of many proclamations and directives thatprogressed the democratization process of the country in the right direction. Moreover\,during the COVID-19 pandemic\, the cooperation partner was involved in thedistribution of protective gears for the most neglected like the prison community. Duringthe escalation of the dispute between the Federal government and the Tigray Regionalgovernment\, the national elders' council attempted several times to have an amicableresolution however this did not happen. The council continued its work during theconflict as well as its' participation in the MIND initiative\, it indirectly contributed tobring the issue of National Dialogue to the public' attention.JFA-PFE's original budget at the start of the agreement and what was then secured had adeficit that required the partner to prioritize amongst the many strategic objectives theyhad set out at the beginning. As such\, the work on 'Child Marriage and Female GenitalMutilation' as well as the work on 'Human rights-sensitive fight of terrorism and extremism' were given less attention to focus on supporting targeted institutions in theirreform agenda.The evaluators note that JFA-PFE has been most strategic/effective to operate onnational level with high level policy advocacy\, perhaps leaving some issues at localgrassroots level to other\, specialized CSOs in the similar field. This observation wasmainly in relation to the strategic objective on GBV. One of the observed shortcoming ofthe cooperation partner is its inability to form and lead a network or coalition of newlyformed CSOs that could help it reach the grassroot level. The geographic reach of theprogram was for the entire country\, even if this meant that the partner stretched toomuch\, it also gave them the flexibility to address various emerging conflicts in the variouscorners of the country.In conclusion\, the evaluators found that the program was relevant\, and as stated above\,the effectiveness could be enhanced if the partner could make use of local CSOs to reachsome of the regional/grass root work on their behalf

column17: PSI (ECRC)2017-2019-National Baseline Assessment and Forest Research,PSI (ECRC)2017-2019-National Baseline Assessment and Forest Research
column20:
Det föreslagna insatsen bidrar avsevärt  till de strategiska resultaten för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete med Etiopien (2016-2020) och den nationella utvecklingsplanen för att tillhandahålla giltig baslinjeinformation för att mäta genomslag ar policy.
Basinformationen kommer att hjälpa statliga och icke-statliga aktörer att pröva prestationen de föreslagna nationella målen och uppfylla åtagandet i Parisavtalet\, dvs. 64% växthusgasutsläppsminskning genom kommunicerad NDC. Resultatet av denna insato kommer därför att gynna olika intressenter som bidrar till viktiaa ekonomiska sektorer\, dvs. jordbruk\, industri\, miljö / klimat\, vatten\, boskap och transporter och stadsutveckling.
Projektet har markerats med det politiska målet "huvudmål" och "viktigt mål" för klimatförändringar\, biologisk mångfald\, kön och ekonomisk utveckling.,The project aims at generation of baseline data as an input to the CRGE’s M&E system\, and assessing the role of sustainable forest management in the implementation of the CRGE strategy.
The project runs over 1and half years and the total budget amounts to 9\, 900 000 SEK. Sida is the sole financier of the project. The project primarily finances salaries\, consultants\, travel and DSA.,The proposed intervention will come up with the following intended development outcomes\,
¤Better access to data  for CRGEs M&E activities 
¤Strengthened capacities of key CRGE partners to make evidence based decisions
¤Improved knowledge sharing  among CRGE stakeholders
¤Reduction of resources spent looking for information for conducting efficient M&E activities
¤Enhanced CRGE related knowledge Management activities with key stakeholders
¤Enhanced  documentation and information of climate related knowledge  sharing of Ethiopia’s experience to the world
column27: Sweden,EDRI/Ethiopian Development Research Institute/Environment and Climate Research Center,Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency,EDRI/Ethiopian Development Research Institute/Environment and Climate Research Center
column91: 13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies\, strategies and planning.,13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik\, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.
column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column200:
The project successfully delivered on the following major results:
1. A total of 82 core idicators set for 8 economic sectors and cross-cutting themes
2. Data base set up at Environment\, Forest climate change Commission for knowlege management
3. Capacity building training offered to sector offices on how to generte data\, analyse and report accordingly
4. Forest reseach crrarried out in three thematic areas (coservation\, development and Marketing)

column17: SIWI 2017-2020: WATER SECURITY IN ETHIOPIA: TRANSLATING POLICY TO IMPACT,SIWI 2017-2020: WATER SECURITY IN ETHIOPIA: TRANSLATING POLICY TO IMPACT
column20:
The project aims at developing a water governance program in Ethiopia with the overall ambition to translate water management policy into implementation through improved water management systems at basin level. The project has 3 components: 1) Capacity building and training of national\, regional and local representatives of relevant institutions in integrated water resource management\, 2) Capacity building for rural communities and farmers in land restoration and management 3) Sector-specific dialogue\, capacity building and education of ministries\, authorities and factories about sustainability in the textile sector (according to the STWI methodology)

The project runs over 4 years and the total budget amounts to 23 300 000 SEK. Sida is the sole financier of the project.

The project primarily funding salaries\, consultants\, travel and accommodation.,Organisationen SIWI har ansökt om medel hos Sida på 23 300 000 SEK för att genomföra projektet "Translating Water Management Policy Into Impact - Strengthening Governance Arrangements At Basin Level" i Etiopien\,  Från September 1\, 2017-december 31\, 2020. Den totala budgeten för 2017-2020 är 23 300 000 och årlig budget för varje år är följande 2017: 9\,3 MSEK; 2018: 6 MSEK; 2019: 5 MSEK; 2020: 3 MSEK.

Projektet syftar till att utveckla ett program för vattenförvaltning i Etiopien med den övergripande ambitionen att översätta vattenförvaltningspolitik till genomförande genom förbättrade styrningssystem i avrinningsområden. Projektet har 3 komponenter: 1) Kapacitetsuppbyggnad och utbildning av nationella\, regionala och lokala representanter från relevanta institutioner i integrerad vattenresursförvaltning\, 2) Kapacitetsuppbyggnad för landsbygdssamhällen och jordbrukare i restaurering och förvaltning av landskap\, 3) Sektorspecifik dialog\, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och utbildning av ministerier\, myndigheter och fabriker om hållbarhet i textilsektorn (enligt STWI-metodiken)

Projektet löper över 4 år (2017-2020) och den totala budgeten uppgår till 23 300 000 kronor. Även om Sida är projektets enda finansierare\, kommer olika institutioner att vara engagerade i projektdesign och implementering. Bland många andra kommer SIWI att engagera offentliga institutioner som ministeriet för bevattning och el (MoWIE)\, ministeriet för miljöskog och klimatförändring (MEFCC)\, industriministeriet (MOI)\, etiopiska textilutvecklingsinstitutet (ETDI) och industriparkens utveckling Att spela aktiv roll i projektdesign\, implementering och M & E-processen. Dessutom kommer lokala universitet att delta i forskningskomponenten för att stödja policy och beslutsprocess med aktuell information. Från den privata sektorns engagemang kommer också textilfabriken ägare och näringslivssektorerna inom textilsektorn som H & M att delta i kapacitetsuppbyggnadsåtgärden.

Eftersom större delen av projektet främst fokuserar på kapacitetsuppbyggnad kommer majoriteten av budgeten att täcka löner\, konsultationer\, resor och boende.,The support to SIWI in Ethiopia is to the programme "Translating water management policy into impact - strengthened governance arrangements at basin level". The impact is defined as the sustainable supply of water for socio-economic development and environmental protection. The programme's theory of change (ToC) is\, in short; Improving the capacity of government institutions with interest and mandate on water (MOWIE\, ETIDI\, EFCC\, Basin Development Authority and basin offices etc) lead to improved water resources management and security at both national and local basin levels in Ethiopia.The programme is made out of three separate work packages that together will create overall change. The overall objectives are:Outcome 1: Enhanced capacity in mandated institutions for Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) implementationOutcome 2: Enhanced local support for and capacity for landscape restoration and managementOutcome 3: Ethiopian Textile Development Institute (ETDI) supports the textile industry to implement sustainable practices and perform integrated risk assessments
column27: Sweden,SIWI/Stockholm International Water Institute,Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency,SIWI/Stockholm International Water Institute
column91: 12.2 - By 2030\, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.,12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.,15.3 - Till 2030 bekämpa ökenspridning\, återställa förstörd mark och jord\, inklusive mark som drabbats av ökenspridning\, torka och översvämningar\, samt sträva efter att uppnå en värld utan nettoförstöring av mark.,15.3 - By 2030\, combat desertification\, restore degraded land and soil\, including land affected by desertification\, drought and floods\, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.,6.4 - By 2030\, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.,6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.,6.5 - By 2030\, implement integrated water resources management at all levels\, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.,6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer\, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.,6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program\, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling\, avsaltning\, vatteneffektivitet\, rening av avloppsvatten\, återvinning och återanvändning.,6.a - By 2030\, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes\, including water harvesting\, desalination\, water efficiency\, wastewater treatment\, recycling and reuse technologies.
column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column200: The support to the Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) is to the programme Translating water management policy into impact". Due to the nature of the programme where support for policy development is done parallel to capacity buiding on federal\, regional and local level\, the final impact takes longer to achieve.Through a combination of activities such as support to the development of Ethiopias National Water Policy and strategy\, institutional capacity building for technical experts and water professionals\, development of basin plans and field manuals\, and establishment of multi-stakeholder platform for sustainable land and water management in Central Rift Valley lakes basin\, the programme has managed to further align policies and strategies with implementation at basin and local level. Some examples are\, by enabling the development of an updated national water policy and strategy that is informed by\, and aligned with basin-level plans and manuals\, has established the foundation needed for a sustainable supply of water for socio-economic development and environmental protection. The multi-stakeholder platform for sustainable land and water management in central rift valley lakes basin that was established in 2021\, contributes to a stronger cooperation between relevant stakeholders with  interest and mandate in water and landscape management issues.Furthermore\, the need for financial investment in the water sector was identified as a critical issue needed to ensure sustainability\, why activities such as training of stakeholders on Private Public Partnershiops\, and support to the development of a strategic document that will function as a fundraising and operational tool for the Ministry of Water and Energy. Finally\, a specific issue to highlight\, where SIWI has proved to be particularly strong\, is the integration of gender and equality issues. The integration of gender has been consistent from the start of the programme\, for example through trainings\, and in 2021 a guidebook for gender mainstreaming in IWRM\, a Policy makers pocketbook on gender mainstreaming were developed to provide Ethiopias policymakers in MOWIE and related directorates with information on how to mainstream gender into IWRM.Some specific results in 2021 to highlight include:WP1: Capacity building to support implementation of IWRM at federal\, basin and local levels- Private Public Partnership training for water professionals to support readiness for investments in the water infrastructure sector.- support to the National Water Policy and Strategy soon to be approved by the cabinet. SIWI has as well managed to add water as a human right to the Strategy.- support to the National Integrated Water Resource Management Program\, a strategic fundraising and operational tool for Ministry of Water and Energy.- technical assistance and leadership for the development of synthesis basin plan of the Rift-valley lakes basin office and four sub-basin plans.- Guidebook for gender mainstreaming in IWRM developed and Policy makers pocketbook on gender mainstreaming is also developed to provide Ethiopias policymakers in MOWIE and related directorates with information on how to mainstream gender into IWRMWP2: Capacity building for Landscape Restoration and Management- Development of\, and training on field manuals on land degradation and restoration\, participatory land use planning (PLUP)\, and water productive and resilient landscape management technologies and approaches\, hydrological impact of water shade management and Management Options to Sustaining Landscape Restoration Measures; The Case of Enclosures and other organizations has as well started using the manuals in their landscape management activities.- Multi stakeholder platform for sustainable land and water management in central rift valley lakes basin  established.WP3: Capacity building for improved water resources use and environmental compliance in textile factories.- Online trainings within environmental and water law\, resource efficiency in textile factories and leadership strategies in changing environments.- institutional capacity development support through online training and individualised coaching targeting officials from EIC\, EFCCC\, MOWIE\, MOIT\, BDA for improved decision-making and programme management.
column219: No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

column17: SMHI 2017-2020: WACCA-Ethiopia:WATER AND CLIMATE CHANGE SERVICES FOR AFRICA,SMHI 2017-2020: WACCA-Ethiopia:WATER AND CLIMATE CHANGE SERVICES FOR AFRICA
column20:
Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Ethiopia) is a country
driven initiative to strengthen and accelerate efforts at national and regional levels across
Ethiopia in the development of climate and water information and early warning services.
Reliable climate information is crucial to meeting key targets in the growth and
transformation plans (GTP)\, nationally determined contributions\, as well as the climate
resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. The National Meteorological Agency\, the
hydrological services under the Ministry of Water\, Irrigation and Electricity and the Ministry
of the Environment\, Forests and Climate Change are charged with the provision of these
information and are the local implementing partners in the WACCA-Ethiopia initiative. The
common aim is to develop technical capacity and institutional sustainability for the provision
of these key services and this initiative is a direct response to this need. It shall also provide
tailored information designed to fit end-under needs with the best available knowledge about
the future climate\, and develop region specific best-practice solutions for adaptation.,Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Etiopien) är ett landsdrivet initiativ för att stärka och påskynda insatser på nationell och regional nivå i Etiopien i utvecklingen av klimat- och vatteninformation samt tidiga varningssystem. Tillförlitlig klimatinformation är avgörande för att möta nyckelmål i Etiopiens utvecklingsplan s.k. Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP II)\, klimatåtagade s.k. "nationally determined contributions" under klimatavtalet samt Etiopiens climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. National Meteorological Agency\, de hydrologiska tjänsterna under Ministry of Water\, Irrigation and Electricity och Ministry of the Environment\, Forests and Climate Change är skyldiga att tillhandahålla denna information och är de lokala genomförandepartnerna i WACCA-Etiopien. Det gemensamma målet är att utveckla teknisk kapacitet och institutionell hållbarhet för att tillhandahålla dessa nyckeltjänster och detta projekt är ett direkt svar på detta behov. Projektet ska också tillhandahålla skräddarsydd information som utformats för att passa de slutliga användarna med den bästa tillgängliga kunskapen om det framtida klimatet och utveckla regionspecifika lösningar för bästa praxis för anpassning.,The WACCA Ethiopia project is designed from the ground up to address specific skills and technical capacity gaps in the water and climate information producing sectors in Ethiopia. It is expected to encompass skills acquisition and technical capacity building of the implementing partners\, improved climate information services\, improved hydrological information services\, strengthened forecasting and early warning systems\, and improved communication and dissemination of related information. The Project will strengthen the countrys water and climate information infrastructure improving both the supply of hydroclimatic data\, information and services from the relevant authorities and mode of delivery to stakeholders and sectors across the country. The end result is to develop sustainable services providing credible and actionable information for the people of Ethiopia\, from decision and policy makers in meeting internally determined climate targets at one end of the spectrum down to enhancing the quality of life and ensuring sustainable livelihoods for the vulnerable people of Ethiopia\, for example\, smallholder farmers or pastoralists at the other end.To achieve these objectives\, SMHI\, in collaboration with local partner organizations\, will work to develop and strengthen climate infrastructure for providing information on climate change\, future water resources\, vulnerability and impacts\, as well as hydrological andclimate modeling and forecasts\, and efficient data management. Of necessity is the strengthening of information and communication pathways between different services and data providers such as the meteorological and hydrological services as well as the disaster risk management authorities. The line of information and communication between different stakeholders such as the agriculture\, energy and health sectors will likewise be addressed at  all levels. This entails providing sector specific information services and targeted\, community focused disaster reduction protocols down to the woreda (district) levels. The initial phase of WACCA Ethiopia will be implemented over a period of 3 years

column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column200:
Following a 6-months inception phase in 2018\, the second year of the WACCA-Ethiopia programme included implementation under all proposed project outcomes\, and within all three work packages (WP 1 - Meteorological and Climate Information Services; WP2 - Hydrological and Water Information Services; WP 3 Communication and Integration)\, and the two cross-cutting themes (Data management and ICT\, and Gender Mainstreaming). 
Focus in 2019 has been on continued support to the Basins Development Authority (BDA) and its Hydrology and Water Quality Directorate (HWQD)\, the National Meterological  Agency (NMA) and the Environment Forest and Climate Change Commission (EFCCC) with refining operational procedures and public services mandates. 
Gender mainstreaming training that includes all three partner organisations has been conducted\, which has been done in close collaboration with SIWI (Stockholm International Water Institute). 
SMHI has during the year fulfilled all planned missions in Ethiopia and Sweden.
Some highlights from project activities during 2019:
- NMA and HWQD expert visit to SMHI to work with SMHI staff on weather forecast\, modelling and early warning service routines and to strengthen strategic partnerships and showcase best practices.
- Design and development of an SOP DokuWiki1 portal on the NMA intranet for further work in standardising NMA operations.
- Training with focus on meteorological forecasting and climate modelling and information services at NMA.
- Training in the field for improved hydrological monitoring\, including instrumentation\, data handling and safety at HWQD.
- Training with focus on hydrological modelling and setting up a hydrological early warning system at HWQD.
- Collaboration established between HWQD\, SMHI and the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) regarding use and support of WMO’s Meteorological\, Climatological and Hydrological Database Management System2 (MCH) for storing and retrieving hydrological observations data at BDA.
- Two local Ethiopian expert consultants have been contracted to complement the SMHI staff\, a senior gender expert and a senior hydrologist\, both of which are highly qualified with many years of relevant experience.
- Workshops on data sharing have been conducted in Norrköping and Addis Ababa where participants preliminarily agreed – in principle – on what data to be shared when and in what quality\, which is critical for improved water\, weather and climate services.
- Field visit near Hawassa with communication experts from NMA\, MoWIE and the three BDA branch offices to discuss access to forecasts (short and long term) with agricultural extension agents and farmers\, which was coordinated with the SIWI project field site selection for development synergy and to ensure consistency in outreach between projects.
- NMA\, MoWIE and BDA visited SMHI to continue with the communications work that begun in the field in Ethiopia and get further training on communication tools for use in disseminating information to agricultural extension agents\, farmers and other stakeholders.
- Collaboration framework established between SMHI and SIWI on conducting gender mainstreaming activities within each of the Ethiopian partner institutions.
- Workshops on gender sensitisation\, gender mainstreaming and sexual harassment in the workplace conducted with officers from MoWIE\, BDA\, EFCCC and NMA.
- Procurement for the hydrological EWS (early warning system) equipment completed and shipped to Ethiopia as part of the development for hydrological early warning services.
- Decisions taken for the use of a majority of the investment funds that will support the Ethiopian institutions with IT-related equipment for better data management and monitoring\, and equipment for improved hydrological field operations.
See statement of annual report for 2019 for further information.
column219: No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

column17: SMHI 2017-2020: WACCA-Ethiopia:WATER AND CLIMATE CHANGE SERVICES FOR AFRICA,SMHI 2017-2020: WACCA-Ethiopia:WATER AND CLIMATE CHANGE SERVICES FOR AFRICA
column20:
Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Ethiopia) is a country
driven initiative to strengthen and accelerate efforts at national and regional levels across
Ethiopia in the development of climate and water information and early warning services.
Reliable climate information is crucial to meeting key targets in the growth and
transformation plans (GTP)\, nationally determined contributions\, as well as the climate
resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. The National Meteorological Agency\, the
hydrological services under the Ministry of Water\, Irrigation and Electricity and the Ministry
of the Environment\, Forests and Climate Change are charged with the provision of these
information and are the local implementing partners in the WACCA-Ethiopia initiative. The
common aim is to develop technical capacity and institutional sustainability for the provision
of these key services and this initiative is a direct response to this need. It shall also provide
tailored information designed to fit end-under needs with the best available knowledge about
the future climate\, and develop region specific best-practice solutions for adaptation.,Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Etiopien) är ett landsdrivet initiativ för att stärka och påskynda insatser på nationell och regional nivå i Etiopien i utvecklingen av klimat- och vatteninformation samt tidiga varningssystem. Tillförlitlig klimatinformation är avgörande för att möta nyckelmål i Etiopiens utvecklingsplan s.k. Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP II)\, klimatåtagade s.k. "nationally determined contributions" under klimatavtalet samt Etiopiens climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. National Meteorological Agency\, de hydrologiska tjänsterna under Ministry of Water\, Irrigation and Electricity och Ministry of the Environment\, Forests and Climate Change är skyldiga att tillhandahålla denna information och är de lokala genomförandepartnerna i WACCA-Etiopien. Det gemensamma målet är att utveckla teknisk kapacitet och institutionell hållbarhet för att tillhandahålla dessa nyckeltjänster och detta projekt är ett direkt svar på detta behov. Projektet ska också tillhandahålla skräddarsydd information som utformats för att passa de slutliga användarna med den bästa tillgängliga kunskapen om det framtida klimatet och utveckla regionspecifika lösningar för bästa praxis för anpassning.,The WACCA Ethiopia project is designed from the ground up to address specific skills and technical capacity gaps in the water and climate information producing sectors in Ethiopia. It is expected to encompass skills acquisition and technical capacity building of the implementing partners\, improved climate information services\, improved hydrological information services\, strengthened forecasting and early warning systems\, and improved communication and dissemination of related information. The Project will strengthen the countrys water and climate information infrastructure improving both the supply of hydroclimatic data\, information and services from the relevant authorities and mode of delivery to stakeholders and sectors across the country. The end result is to develop sustainable services providing credible and actionable information for the people of Ethiopia\, from decision and policy makers in meeting internally determined climate targets at one end of the spectrum down to enhancing the quality of life and ensuring sustainable livelihoods for the vulnerable people of Ethiopia\, for example\, smallholder farmers or pastoralists at the other end.To achieve these objectives\, SMHI\, in collaboration with local partner organizations\, will work to develop and strengthen climate infrastructure for providing information on climate change\, future water resources\, vulnerability and impacts\, as well as hydrological andclimate modeling and forecasts\, and efficient data management. Of necessity is the strengthening of information and communication pathways between different services and data providers such as the meteorological and hydrological services as well as the disaster risk management authorities. The line of information and communication between different stakeholders such as the agriculture\, energy and health sectors will likewise be addressed at  all levels. This entails providing sector specific information services and targeted\, community focused disaster reduction protocols down to the woreda (district) levels. The initial phase of WACCA Ethiopia will be implemented over a period of 3 years

column200:
Following a 6-months inception phase in 2018\, the second year of the WACCA-Ethiopia programme included implementation under all proposed project outcomes\, and within all three work packages (WP 1 - Meteorological and Climate Information Services; WP2 - Hydrological and Water Information Services; WP 3 Communication and Integration)\, and the two cross-cutting themes (Data management and ICT\, and Gender Mainstreaming). 
Focus in 2019 has been on continued support to the Basins Development Authority (BDA) and its Hydrology and Water Quality Directorate (HWQD)\, the National Meterological  Agency (NMA) and the Environment Forest and Climate Change Commission (EFCCC) with refining operational procedures and public services mandates. 
Gender mainstreaming training that includes all three partner organisations has been conducted\, which has been done in close collaboration with SIWI (Stockholm International Water Institute). 
SMHI has during the year fulfilled all planned missions in Ethiopia and Sweden.
Some highlights from project activities during 2019:
- NMA and HWQD expert visit to SMHI to work with SMHI staff on weather forecast\, modelling and early warning service routines and to strengthen strategic partnerships and showcase best practices.
- Design and development of an SOP DokuWiki1 portal on the NMA intranet for further work in standardising NMA operations.
- Training with focus on meteorological forecasting and climate modelling and information services at NMA.
- Training in the field for improved hydrological monitoring\, including instrumentation\, data handling and safety at HWQD.
- Training with focus on hydrological modelling and setting up a hydrological early warning system at HWQD.
- Collaboration established between HWQD\, SMHI and the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) regarding use and support of WMO’s Meteorological\, Climatological and Hydrological Database Management System2 (MCH) for storing and retrieving hydrological observations data at BDA.
- Two local Ethiopian expert consultants have been contracted to complement the SMHI staff\, a senior gender expert and a senior hydrologist\, both of which are highly qualified with many years of relevant experience.
- Workshops on data sharing have been conducted in Norrköping and Addis Ababa where participants preliminarily agreed – in principle – on what data to be shared when and in what quality\, which is critical for improved water\, weather and climate services.
- Field visit near Hawassa with communication experts from NMA\, MoWIE and the three BDA branch offices to discuss access to forecasts (short and long term) with agricultural extension agents and farmers\, which was coordinated with the SIWI project field site selection for development synergy and to ensure consistency in outreach between projects.
- NMA\, MoWIE and BDA visited SMHI to continue with the communications work that begun in the field in Ethiopia and get further training on communication tools for use in disseminating information to agricultural extension agents\, farmers and other stakeholders.
- Collaboration framework established between SMHI and SIWI on conducting gender mainstreaming activities within each of the Ethiopian partner institutions.
- Workshops on gender sensitisation\, gender mainstreaming and sexual harassment in the workplace conducted with officers from MoWIE\, BDA\, EFCCC and NMA.
- Procurement for the hydrological EWS (early warning system) equipment completed and shipped to Ethiopia as part of the development for hydrological early warning services.
- Decisions taken for the use of a majority of the investment funds that will support the Ethiopian institutions with IT-related equipment for better data management and monitoring\, and equipment for improved hydrological field operations.
See statement of annual report for 2019 for further information.

column17: JeCCDO - (2018-2022) Engaging Community Structures towards local development,JeCCDO - (2018-2022) Engaging Community Structures towards local development
column20:
The goal of the programme is to improve transparency\, accountability and participation in order to promote good governance at local level. The programme will strengthen both duty bearers and right holders to collaborate more closely and effectively. Capacity and awareness about the value of inviting and listening to the citizens will be a priority and so will capacity building for citizens to raise their voice and participate in local planning\, budgeting and decision making be. Sustained platforms for dialogue\, collaboration and negotiations will also be strengthen through the programme.,Målet med insatsen är att bidra till god samhällsstyrning genom attstärka öppenhet\, ansvarstagande och deltagande på lokal nivå.Insatsen syftar till att stärka både statliga aktörer och medborgare och dess representanter.Båda parter ska erhålla ökad kunskap och kapacitet om metoder och former för närmare och effektivare samarbete. Insatsen syftar vidare till att skapa förutsättningar för ökad deltagande och möjlihget att påverka lokala beslut om service till medborgarna.,The objective of the intervention is to enhance participation\, accountability and transparency in local development process. It's based on the premise that both government officials and citizens need to play a role in moving the development process forward. In the Ethiopian context\, development is conceived to be the task/sphere of the government where citizens have no role or little role to play. Hence\, the intervention seeks to bring about change in this flawed conception by building the capacity of both the demand and the supply sides; it aims at developing the skills of citizens (through their grassroots institutions) to engage in matters that affect their lives and to actively participate in all local development agenda.
At the same time\, the intervention seeks at enhancing government officials' ability to listen to citizens' demands and at developing a culture of dialogue whereby openness\, transparency and accountability in local governance is upheld. Furthermore\, in accomplishing the above mentioned objective\, the intervention aims at focusing on disadvantaged groups\, particularly women and girls.
At end of the intervention\, the intervention seeks to achieve the following:
-Enhanced capacity of target community structures and local governments to engage towards pro-poor and gender sensitive local development process and sustainable solution in poverty reduction.
- Inclusion\, voice and capacity of disadvantaged groups (mainly women) to effectively engage in their local development agendas is promoted.
- Enhanced awareness\, knowledge and commitment of the public towards the protection and improvement  of socio-cultural\, and economic status of women.
-Girls' participation in leadership\, civic values and school based social entrepreneurship is nurtured.
- Target community structures and local governments are enabled to jointly assess project performance and share lessons both to maximize project benefits; learning for improvements in future programming is ensured.

column17: Capacity Development Programme Climate/Sus cities,Kapacitetsutvecklingsprogram Klimat/Hållbara städer (Naturvårdsverket)
column20: This global capacity building program\, "Strengthened Institutions for a Sustainable Climate"\, is based on the Swedish authorities' work for Agenda 2030 in Sida's partner countries. Through this effort\, Sida supports innovative methods for cooperation between Swedish authorities and their counterparts in countries in Africa. Kenya\, Uganda\, Zimbabwe\, Ethiopia and Zambia are included in the initial selection group. During the program period 2018-2024 there is potential to involve more countries and a long-term goal is that the program will develop models for capacity development that can be applied in other contexts and other development areas in future programs.\nThe program focuses on accessible and user-friendly climate information systems and on inclusive\, sustainable urban planning. The focus on climate transparency issues within the Paris Agreement involves supporting central administration to develop robust tools and methods that the parties to the agreement must establish in order to be able to measure\, monitor and verify (MRV) greenhouse gas emissions\, but also indicators for sustainable development. MRV is central to the implementation and follow-up of each countries own GHG emissions.\nThe second focus of the program concerns inclusive urban planning and aims to strengthen the capacity of administrations at national level to achieve sustainable urbanization with a climate and ecosystem services perspective based on good governance principles.,Detta globala kapacitetsbyggande program\, "Strengthened Institutions for a Sustainable Climate" (Stärkta institutioner för ett hållbart klimat)\, tar sin utgångspunkt i svenska myndigheters arbete för Agenda 2030 i Sidas samarbetsländer. Genom insatsen stödjer Sida innovativa metoder för samverkan mellan svenska myndigheter och sina motsvarigheter i fyra länder i Afrika. Kenya\, Uganda\, Zimbabwe\, Etiopien och Zambia ingår i den initiala urvalsgruppen. Under programperioden 2018-2024 finns potential att involvera fler länder och en långsiktig målsättning är att programmet ska utveckla modeller för kapacitetsutveckling som i kommande programsatsningar ska kunna appliceras i andra kontexter och inom andra utvecklingsområden. Programmet inriktas dels på system för tillgänglig och användarvänlig klimatinformation\, dels på inkluderande\, hållbar stadsplanering. Inriktningen på transparensfrågorna på klimatområdet inom Parisavtalet innebär att stödja central förvaltning att utveckla robusta verktyg och metoder som avtalets parter måste upprätta för att kunna mäta\, följa upp och verifiera (MRV) utsläpp av växthusgaser\, men också indikatorer för hållbar utveckling. MRV är centralt för genomförandet och uppföljningen av länders National Determined Contributions (NDC). MRV/transparens är därtill ett svenskt styrkeområde\, både vad gäller landets egna uppföljning och vad gäller tidigare samarbeten på t.ex. forskningsnivå visavi utvecklingsländer. Programmets andra inriktning rör inkluderande stadsplanering och syftar till att förstärka kapaciteten hos förvaltningar på nationell nivå för att uppnå hållbar urbanisering med ett klimat- och ekosystemtjänstperspektiv baserat på goda förvaltningsprinciper. Att en allt större andel av världens befolkning söker sig till städer innebär stora hållbarhetsutmaningar när det gäller bostäder\, infrastruktur\, grundläggande service\, växande ojämlikhet och miljöförstöring. Också på detta område har Sverige gedigna erfarenheter och kan bidra med modeller och arbetssätt för hur förvaltning på central nivå kan samordna aktörer och utveckla hållbara principer för stadsutveckling.De båda inriktningarna har flera beröringspunkter och är högt prioriterade i Sidas strategier och av länderna i fråga. Klimatförändringar har en ökande påverkan på människor och ekosystem. Fattiga och sårbara grupper i utvecklingsländer påverkas ofta oproportionerligt av klimatförändringar och dess effekter pga deras sårbarhet och låga kapacitet att klara av yttre chocker som översvämningar och torka. Tillgång till vatten och andra sanitära behov påverkas också direkt eller indirekt\, inte minst i den urbana kontexten.   Programmet löper över fem år och har en beräknad budget på SEK 49 500 000\, inkl. en inledande uppstartsfas (Inception Phase). Ett tydligt särdrag i programmet är att fokus ligger på central förvaltning\, dvs. de svenska myndigheternas direkta motsvarigheter\, vilket kommer att innebära direkt kollegialt utbyte och i förlängningen skapa förtroende och partnerskap mellan tjänstemän. Lika viktig för programmets måluppfyllese är peer-to-peer learning mellan tjänstemän ifrån deltagande länder. Regionala workshops för kunskapsutbyte ingår under hela programmet där deltagare både delar specifika erfarenheter kring förändringsprojekt och andra relaterade utmaningar de står inför. Kapacitetsutvecklingen är därutöver långsiktig och ska bygga på ett systemanpassat arbetssätt som innebär att olika funktioner/instanser/nivåer inom utvalda politikområden ska ta del av insatsen och vara involverade i respektive förändringsprocess. Sida bedömer att insatsen tydligt svarar upp mot flera behov i föreslagna samarbetsländer i Afrika och kompletterar andra Sidastödda och andra pågående processer samt har potential att bidra med lärande ikring metodik för kapacitetsutveckling.  Det Sidaledda projektet Myndigheter för Agenda 2030 operationaliseras genom aktuell insats då sju svenska expertmyndigheter tillsammans samskapar och mobiliserar för att stödja institutionell utveckling. Insatsen har designats av svenska expertmyndigheter utifrån deras ämnesmässiga kompetens samt utifrån gap som länderna själva har identifierat. Tillsammans med Sida har genomförarna sedan justerat erbjudandet så att det matchar den efterfrågan som finns på relevant kapacitetsutveckling i länderna.  Insatsen har potential att stå modell för hur svenska myndigheter\, men också andra samhällsaktörer\, kan samverka för att möta efterfrågan i utvecklingskontexter. Programmet kommer att vara adaptivt och flexibelt i bemärkelsen att myndighetsgruppen kommer att kunna anpassa inriktning och nivå på kapacitetsutvecklingen efter behov och kontext i resp. samarbetsland. Förberedelsearbetet under uppstartsfasen tillsammans med nyckelorganisationer i länderna kommer därför vara av stor betydelse. Genomförandet kommer därtill kompletteras med en modul för kontinuerligt lärande och uppföljning som stödjer genomförarna att justera innehåll och metoder till aktuell målgrupp/förvaltning.,Detta globala kapacitetsbyggande program\, "Strengthened Institutions for a Sustainable Climate" (Stärkta institutioner för ett hållbart klimat)\, tar sin utgångspunkt i svenska myndigheters arbete för Agenda 2030 i Sidas samarbetsländer. Genom insatsen stödjer Sida innovativa metoder för samverkan mellan svenska myndigheter och sina motsvarigheter i sju länder i Afrika: Kenya\, Uganda\, Zimbabwe\, Etiopien\, Moçambique\, Zambia och Rwanda.Programmet inriktas dels på system för tillgänglig och användarvänlig klimatinformation\, dels på inkluderande och hållbar stadsplanering. Inriktningen på transparensfrågorna på klimatområdet inom Parisavtalet innebär att stödja central förvaltning att utveckla robusta verktyg och metoder som avtalets parter måste upprätta för att kunna mäta\, följa upp och verifiera (MRV) utsläpp av växthusgaser\, men också indikatorer för hållbar utveckling. MRV är centralt för genomförandet och uppföljningen av ländernas National Determined Contributions (NDC). MRV och transparens är därtill ett svenskt styrkeområde\, både vad gäller landets egna uppföljning och vad gäller tidigare samarbeten med partnerländer. Programmets andra inriktning rör inkluderande stadsplanering och syftar till att förstärka kapaciteten hos förvaltningar på nationell nivå för att uppnå hållbar urbanisering med ett klimat- och ekosystemtjänstperspektiv baserat på goda förvaltningsprinciper. Att en allt större andel av världens befolkning söker sig till städer innebär stora hållbarhetsutmaningar när det gäller bostäder\, infrastruktur\, grundläggande service\, växande ojämlikhet och miljöförstöring. Också på detta område har Sverige gedigna erfarenheter och kan bidra med modeller och arbetssätt för hur förvaltning på central nivå kan samordna aktörer och utveckla hållbara principer för stadsutveckling.De båda inriktningarna har flera beröringspunkter och är högt prioriterade i Sidas strategier och av länderna i fråga. Klimatförändringar har en ökande påverkan på människor och ekosystem. Fattiga och sårbara grupper i utvecklingsländer påverkas ofta oproportionerligt av klimatförändringar och dess effekter på grund av deras sårbarhet och låga kapacitet att klara av yttre störningar som översvämningar och torka. Tillgång till vatten och andra sanitära behov påverkas också direkt eller indirekt\, inte minst i den urbana kontexten.Ett tydligt särdrag i programmet är att fokus ligger på central förvaltning\, dvs. de svenska myndigheternas direkta motsvarigheter\, vilket kommer att innebära direkt kollegialt utbyte och i förlängningen skapa förtroende och partnerskap mellan tjänstemän. Lika viktig för programmets måluppfyllelse är peer-to-peer learning mellan tjänstemän från deltagande länder. Regionala workshops för kunskapsutbyte ingår under hela programmet där deltagare både delar specifika erfarenheter kring förändringsprojekt och andra relaterade utmaningar de står inför. Kapacitetsutvecklingen är därutöver långsiktig och ska bygga på ett system anpassat arbetssätt som innebär att olika funktioner/instanser/nivåer inom utvalda politikområden ska ta del av insatsen och vara involverade i respektive förändringsprocess.

column180: Beslut om avtalsändring,Överenskommelse för bidrag till Naturvårdsverket,Beslut om insats
column200: Förutom de aktiviteter som finns under projektarbete så har myndighetspersonal haft besök och mentor- aktiviteter med flera partners i Mocambique\, Rwanda\, Uganda\, Kenya och Zimbabwe under 2022.Projektarbetet : Från att vara 17 olika projekt under programmet\, har man konsoliderat till 7 pågående projekt\, 4 inom klimatdata och klimatförändring och 3 inom urbanisering. Ett projekt i Uganda inom klimatdata "Enhanced GHG Inventory" avslutas under tidigt 2023 vilket innebär att 6 projekt återstår\, 3 inom varje målområde.De klimatdata inriktad projekt som är kvar är i Rwanda och Mozambique\, där Naturvårdsverket samarbetar med SLU och SCB i genomförandet av klimatdata samling och analys som bidrar till ländernas förbättring av rapportering om NDC (National Determined Contributions) och visar ländernas bidrag till globala målen.SMHIs project i Migori County\, Kenya är inriktad mot klimatanpassning. Där är syftet att integrera klimatfrågor på det lokalnivå. 22 anställda (utbildare) från Migori miljöenhet och alla medlemmar i planeringskommittéer för klimatförändringar (ca 500) och kenyanska tränare har deltagit i flera träningsövningar där kunskap om varför och bra exempel om hur man integrera åtgärder för anpassning till och begränsning av klimatförändringar i planeringen och beslutsfattande. Hela projektet är en fortsättning av ett förändringsprojekt från ett annat program (ITP Climate Change).De tre hållbar urbanisering projekt "Eco Settlement Social Planning" (Kenya)\, "Social Planning for Inclusive and Resilient Urban Dev" (Uganda) och "Interplay mobility\, Climate Change\, and Design for Urban Resilience"(Zimbabwe) har organiserat en samlingsworkshop i Blekinge och Stockholm för att utveckla samarbetet.Samarbetet mellan Boverket och Blekinge Tekniska Universitet har tillsammans samlat flera lokala partners i Kenya Kenyatta univ\, Civil Society for Urban Dev Platform (CSUDP)\, Nairobi univ.\, Tangaza univ.\, NGO Palmoja Trust och Kenya Department of Housing and Urban Development samt universitet  i Uganda och Zimababwe.Urban grupp gjorde ett översyn av befintliga akademiska program för stads och regionalplanering\, följde av ett behovsanalys och marknadsundersökning för att hitta synergier. Målet är att bilda ett regionalt nätverk för urban resiliens med fokus på samarbete om läroplaner för utbildning\, utbyte och kapacitetsuppbyggnad och för att utveckla praktiska metoder för att lära ut holistisk stadsplanering som tar hänsyn till klimatförändrings utmaningar.  Arbetet fortgår under 2023 med workshops för att samsas om läroplaner (curriculum) och möjliggör utbytes tillfälle mellan ländernas universitet personal och stadsplanerare.

column17: MSB - agreement 2018 - 2020,MSB - överenskommelse 2018-2020
column20:
MSB (the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency) is a Swedish agency tasked with providing and supporting humanitarian operations and interventions. This agreement sets out the Humanitarian Framework for all humanitarian contributions financed by Sida's Humanitarian Unit in which MSB is the Swedish government agency providing operative capacity to humanitarian interventions\, through contributions in the form of secondments\, the establishment of humanitarian base camps and shelters\, medical teams etc in support of UN Organizations. In addition\, MSB complement their humanitarian work through their own contributions in capacity development projects in connection with the establishment of rescue services.

Sida and MSB has worked closely together within the framework for swedish humanitarian assistance since 2006 and this partnership has previously shown good results\, in particular with regards to MSB’s ability to provide operational and technical assistance to humanitarian actors in both protracted and sudden onset emergencies. The UN agencies are the most common benefactor of such surge deployments and secondments. In addition\, MSB has constructed base camps in Nigeria to improve access and seconded personnel to improve emergency response planning in Iraq. 

MSB’s interventions and contributions consist of surge deployments\, secondment of technical expertise\, construction of base camps and material support to humanitarian actors\, based on demands. For each calendar year\, MSB develop an annual strategic plan in accordance with this agreement\, to guide their humanitarian work\, which is submitted and approved by Sida. This agreement was initially signed for a three-year period (2018-2020) but was later extended by 1 year to cover the period 2018-2021\, with a total allocation of 450 MSEK from Sida to MSB.,Myndigheten för Samhällsskydd och Beredskap (MSB) är en svensk myndighet som i enlighet med sin instruktion ska kunna medverka med insatser i Sveriges internationella humanitära verksamhet. Detta innebär att MSB är den svenska myndighet som operativt bidrar till effektiv humanitär respons på plats genom att de har kapacitet att snabbt svara upp mot behov som uppstått hos humanitära aktörer i fält via sin surgekapacitet. Insatserna omfattar exempelvis sekonderingar\, basläger\, medicinska team och minröjning. Sida har samarbetat med MSB och den tidigare myndigheten Räddningsverket inom ramen för det humanitära biståndet sedan 2006. Under föregående överenskommelse har MSB visat på god resultatuppfyllelse samt bedömts av Sida spela en relevant roll i det humanitära biståndet genom dess möjlighet att bidra till humanitära organisationers kapacitet att svara upp mot hastigt förändrade eller förvärrade behov i kriser och konflikter. Exempelvis genom etablerandet av basläger i Nigeria för ökad humanitär närvaro och sekonderad personal för att stärka arbetet med responsplanering i Irak. Traditionellt sker samarbetet till stor del med FN organisationer.Insatser med MSB innefattar personellt och materiellt stöd till humanitära organisationer baserat på deras efterfrågan. MSB definierar i sin årsplan den strategiska inriktningen för respektive år vilken godkänns av Sida. Överenskommelsen var ursprunglig treårig (2018-2020) men förlängdes senare med ett år för att täcka perioden 2018-2021 och omfattar totalt 450 MSEK.,Målet med insatsen är: Rädda liv\, lindra nöd\, skydda egendom och värna miljö\, främja frihet och säkerhet samt stärka motståndskraft mot kriser och katastrofer i samhället.
MSBs resultatramverk specificerar förväntad outcome och intermediate outcomes per effektområde. För respektive effektområde är förväntad outcome följande:
- Hantering: Kris- och katastrofhantering är behovsbaserad\, effektiv och samordnad.
- Återhämtning: Kris- och katastrofhantering integrerar återinrättandet av centrala samhällsfunktioner och återhämtande förmåga. 
- Resiliens: Effektiv hantering av kris- och katastrofrisker stärker resiliens i samhället.
