column17: COVID-19 RBA in SRHR\, EngenderHealth\, 2019-2023,COVID-19 RBA inom SRHR\, EngenderHealth\, 2019-2023
column20:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19
Den förslagna insatsens syfte är att bidra till rättighetsbaserad samt ökad tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR) services i Etiopien. Detta syfte är högst relevanta i den etiopiska kontexten där det beräknas att över en tredjedel av tonåringar och ungdomar inte har tillgång till sådana tjänster. Mer specifikt\, insatsen syftar till att främja följande rättigheter:-Rätten att själva bestämma om\, när och hur många barn man ska ha. -Rätten till SRHR-relaterad information och services. -Rätten att vara fri från könsrelaterat våld.För att uppnå detta mål kommer unga kvinnors och mäns egenmakt att stärkas som ”rättighetsbärare” för kunna kräva sina SRHR medans service leverantörer och utbildare kommer att stärkas som ”ansvarstagare” för att skapa en möjliggörande miljö för unga människor att utöva sina rättigheter. Insatsens fokus är därför: -Förbättra kvinnors och flickors förmåga till att utöva sina SRHR.-Förbättra ansvarsutkrävning avseende ansvarstagare och minska diskriminering av kvinnors och flickors tillgång till SRHR-information och service.-Stärka den möjliggörande miljön på interpersonell- och familjenivå för att stödja kvinnor och flickor att kräva och utöva SRHR.Fokus kommer att omfatta uppföljning och utvärdering och lärande. Totalt kommer insatsen att nå 7680 flickor och pojkar i Addis Ababa under tre år.Projektet kommer att piloteras i Addis Abeba\, med målet att skapa en replikerbar modell för att expandera till andra områden efter piloten. Addis Abeba har valts ut som pilotplats främst på grund av de stora koncentrationerna av unga människor och den ökande migrationsgraden till staden från landsbygden.,Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19
The focus of the project is to:
-Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR in Ethiopia.
-Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services.
-Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHR.

In order to achieve this goal\, young women and men will be empowered as the “rights holders” to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the “duty bearers” to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights. 


Focus will also be on monitoring and evaluation and learning. 

The project will reach 7\,680 girls and boys over three years.
The project will be piloted in Addis Ababa\, with the aim to create a replicable model to expand into other areas after the pilot. Addis Ababa has been selected as the pilot location primarily for the large concentrations of young people and the increasing rates of migration into the city from rural areas.,The overarching goal of this intervention is that women and girls fulfil their SRHRs. The specific focus of the project will\, furthermore\, be on the rights that are at the core of the international conference on population and development (ICPD): right to decide\, if\, when\, and how many children to have; right to SRH-related information and services; and\, right to be free from violence.
In order to achieve this goal\, young women and men will be empowered as the ‘rights holders’ to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the ‘duty bearers’ to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights. The project stipulates the following objectives:
-Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR.-Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services.-Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHRs.
There is also an objective dedicated to monitoring and evaluation as well as learning.

column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column180: Decision,Agreement
column200:
During 2020\, the cooperation partner has\, despite Covid-19 related challenges managed to achieve a number of results. These include but are not limited to:
- Covid-19 media awareness campaigns that integrated SGBV and SRHR messaging using TV talk shows and radio programmes. These are estimated to have reached approximately 50 million people and 2.5 million people\, respectively. 
- Rapid assessment of weak spots and barriers in SRHR education and the drafting of a curriculum that integrates SRHR and life skills. Based on rapid assessment\, using two languages (Amharic and Oromiffa) age-appropriate and educational video spots on SGBV and SRHR were developed and broad casted through one TV station (AfriHealth TV) dedicated for media based education. In addition\, the messages were disseminated using social media platforms such as Telegram\, Facebook\, YouTube and Twitter. Through these intervention\, approximately 246\,587 young individuals aged between 13-34 were reached. 
- To improve the knowledge\, skills\, and attitudes of educators on SRHR integrated with Covid-19 response\, the project trained 97 biology teachers (20 females and 77 males)\, school principals and biology department leads (80 biology teachers\, 8 school principals and 8 biology department leads) on adolescent and youth health. This included SRHR\, gender-responsive facilitation skills for SRHR topic and transformation manual to enable reflection on harmful norms\, biases and prejudices that impede full access to SRHR for young people.
- The project collaborated with the Addis Ababa Police Commission to expand helpline services for SGBV response and support. With this intervention\, SGBV survivors now have access to support from police officers\, psychological counselors and lawyers\, and thus can be provided with legal services\, counseled\, and referred to health facilities. 
- In addition to the expanded helpline\, the project also piloted community-based structures to prevent GBV. This included  setting up GBV prevention committees in selected districts in 10 sub-cities and subsequently training 445 committee members\, ranging from religious leaders\, local police\, youth leaders etc. This was done to improve accountability on community level and improve GBV survivor referral systems and data collection for local administrations.

column17: AECF 2017-24 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT),AECF 2017-24 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT)
column20:
The contribution consists of support to a Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy\, Adaptation and Climate Change Technology). REACT - sub-Saharan Africa\, is administered by Afica Enterprise Challenge Fund Ltd (AECF)\, a non-profit company with AGRA (African Green Revolution) as the sole owner/member. AGRA is a "“non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. The contribution includes components in seven of Sweden's cooperation countries and the regional strategy for sub-Saharan Africa.

The objective of REACT is to stimulate small and medium-sized companies\, to develop business models\, services and products in renewable energy and energy efficiency that improve the lives of the poor. The idea is that companies supported by REACT are prepared to take risks\, which they otherwise would not take. The ideas put forward by the companies\, are identified through competitions in the respective countries. Applications are assessed on the basis of clear and transparent criteria and in three separate steps - this\, to assure an independent and transparent process. REACT also supports capacity development of enterprises in a variety of areas\, brokering service for successful companies to access capital for scaling up\, learning and advocacy on national and regional issues (laws\, rules\, licensing\, trade barriers etc.).

The decision on the intervention covers five years and amounts to 400 000 000 SEK.,Insatsen består av ett stöd till en Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy\, Adaptation and Climate Technology). REACT administreras av Africa Enterprise Challenge Fund Ldt (AECF)\, med Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) som enda ägare/medlem. AECF är ett icke-vinstdrivande företag och AGRA är en "non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. AECF är registrerat på Mauritus som bedömts som det afrikanska land som har den mest lämpliga företagslagstiftningen för att kunna bedriva AECF's verksamhet. För att få bedriva verksamhet utanför Mauritius finns bara alternativet "Global Business Licence" enligt gällande lagstiftning.

Insatsen omfattar sju av Sveriges samarbetsländer samt den regionala strategin för Afrika söder om Sahara. 

Syftet med REACT är att stimulera små och medelstora företag\, att utveckla affärsmodeller\, service och produkter inom förnybar energi som förbättrar livet för fattiga. REACT bygger på att företagen med stöd från REACT är beredda att ta risker de annars inte skulle göra. Företagen identifieras via tävlingar i de respektive länderna\, där ansökningar bedöms utifrån tydliga och transparenta kriterier. Urvalet görs i tre steg\, och med hjälp av olika aktörer för varje steg. Detta för att säkerställa en oberoende och öppen process. I stödet ingår även insatser för kapacitetsutveckling av förtagen inom en rad olika områden\, märklarservice för framgångsrika företag att få tillgång till kapital för att utöka sin verksamhet\, lärande och påverkansarbete i nationella och regionala frågor (lagar\, handelshinder etc.). Totalt ska cirka 324 000 hushåll få förbättrad tillgång till förnybar energi samtidigt som cirka 200 000 ton CO2 utsläpp undviks.

Insatsbeslutet är femårigt och uppgår totalt till 400 MSEK. Av beloppet avsätts 2 MSEK inom den regionala strategin för extern uppföljning och bedömning av resultat samt för att bidra till lärande mellan olika länder.,Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies Sub-Saharan Africa(REACT SSA) is a Challenge Fund (CF) program implemented by the Africa EnterpriseChallenge Fund (AECF). The objective of the program is to improve access to renewableenergy for low-income off-grid households\, increase incomes and reduce greenhouse gasemissions in eight target countries. The broader outcome is to catalyse private sectorinvestment and innovation in low-cost clean energy and climate change at scale.The program funds small and growing businesses in the renewable energy sector\, tocatalyse and test the viability of innovative business models that can accelerate progresstowards Universal Access to Energy and address the Climate change challenge.Financing is complemented with Technical advisory (TA) and Investment supportservices to improve viability and ensure company growth. By de-risking unique businessmodels REACT SSA supports the private sector to innovate and invest in diversetechnologies.

Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor\, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta\, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser\, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster\, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv\, naturresurser\, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster\, inklusive mikrokrediter.,17.3 - By 2030\, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to clean energy research and technology\, including renewable energy\, energy efficiency and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology\, and promote investment in energy infrastructure and clean energy technology.

column180: Decision 51050106 AECF 2017-22 REACT,AECF 2017-22 REnewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies,Agreement on REACT- AECF,Grant Agreement,Agreement on REACT- AECF,Decision on contribution AECF / REACT,AECF 2017-22 REnewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies-Agreement
column200: As of June 2022 the REACT SSA program at consolidated level has contracted a total of88 companies\, contributed to 200 000 people enabled with access to clean energy\,generated 1900 jobs\, mobilized USD 44 million and avoided over 497 Kt of C02emissions (cumulative). Results are broadly in line with the contracted targets\, for no.households reached with new or improved energy access (83% target achievement)\, Jobgeneration (90%)\, Mobilisation of capital (255%) and CO2e avoided (3200%). Theprogram has been successful in its poverty outreach\, where targets in terms of outreachto Poor households (150%) as well as Rural/peri-urban households (109%) have bothbeen overachieved. In fact\, clear testimony was found that REACT SSA support hadbeen crucial in enabling and incentivising investees to expand into areas considered ÄleftbehindÅ to reach poor customers in the mid-term review of the program conductedduring the year. For instance\, SHS companies in both Liberia and Mozambiquereported targeting lower income customers or focusing more on Tier 1-2 systems due totheir REACT SSA grant. An MFI in Zimbabwe offering loans for SHS was able toreduce their interest rates and reach more rural customers\, which they were unable to dopreviously when they were financing purely through loans at 24% per annum.A challenge has been to reach the target of generating 50% jobs for Women\, wheretarget fulfilment currently reaches 28%. Meanwhile\, end-beneficiary outreach has beenmore successful\, where 42% of customers are female. Investees have specifically reportdifficulties recruiting women who are willing to be sales agents\, largely due to aperception/reality that these jobs require a lot of time in the field\, and their experience isthat women are more keen to take back office jobs within the company. AECF's Genderteam is now considering how additional support may be provided to this area (e.g. howcan sales agents roles be structured to attract more women)\, especially as this may alsoresult in securing more women headed households as customers.Result achievements on country component level largely reflect those on aggregatedlevel\, meaning outcomes are principally progressing in line with expectations. Strongestperformance is found on the indicators of Households reached with new or improvedenergy access\, Jobs created\, mobilisation of capital\, and Co2e avoided. More prominentvariations of results between countries can be found especially between e.g. the indicatorsMW capacity installed and CO2e avoided\, which beyond purely performance ofindividual companies\, can mainly be accredited to the composition of technologies thatare supported within each country portfolio. For instance\, in Kenya\, Mozambique andBurkina Faso a number of successful clean cooking companies can be found in theportfolios Ê resulting in a thousandfold overachievement of originally contracted CO2etargets. Zimbabwe instead performs strongest on the Job creation indicator (208%)\, astwo microfinance institutions have been the strongest companies in the portfolio\, withoperations that require a larger number of staff. Whereas e.g. Mali and Liberiaoutperforms with approximately 200% on the indicator Households reached with new orimproved energy access\, as a nano and a mini-grid company respectively have beenparticularly successful in these markets.

column17: AAU 2018-2023\, Forskningsutbildning och kapacitetshöjning AAU,AAU 2018-2023\, Research training and capacity building at AAU
column20:
Addis Abeba University has applied to Sida for funding of 196 000 000 SEK to carry out the "Support to Research Training and Capacity Building at Addis Abeba University 2018-2023" program.The objective of the intervention is to strengthen the capacities of Ethiopian Higher Education and Research to meet the poverty reduction strategy of the country by supporting PhD program expansion at Addis Abeba University\, to develop and offer multidisciplinary graduate programs in all relevant fields that are pertinent to the development goals of the nation. The intervention has the following specific objectives:- To launch and execute in-house PhD programs\,- To strengthen the existing research capacity of the university\,- To automate property\, procurement and human resourses management and student records\,- To support administrative and academic reforms\,- To strengthen the university-industry linkage and technology transfer\,- To improve library services and to enhance research facilities commensurate to the existing and envisaged PhD programs.The intervention is divided in two parts\, a) research infrastructure\, research management and research at AAU\, and b) institutional co-operations between AAU and Swedish universities.The first part includes support to Information and Communication Technology ICT\, library\, quality assurance\, university-industry linkage and technology transfer\, gender office\, supervisor training and gender support\, support to the Sida Projects Coordination Office as well as support to the AAU Graduate Programs - visiting professors and examiners and Ethiopian PhD students visits abroad. Also included support to thematic research\, to 5 competetive grants.The second part includes institutional co-operation in four areas; comparative international education\, business management and economics\, biotechnology and electrical engineering. Swedish universities involved are; Gothenburg university\, Jönköping University and Gothenburg university\, Swedish university of Agricultural Sciences as well as Chalmers and Royal Institute of Technology\, respectively. The intervention´s total budget is 196 000 000 SEK\, the total budget for the first part 45 700 000 SEK and for the second part 142 700 000  SEK. In addition Uppsala University/International Science Program (ISP) has a budget of 4 300 000 SEK for coordination of Swedish university partners\, and Sida reserves 3 000 000 SEK within the allocation for other expenses\, forseen to be connected primarily with extra reviews\, gender activites\, supervisor trainings and Result Based Management trainings.  In the institutional co-operation in electrical engineering\, Ethiopian PhD-students will spend some time in Sweden - at Chalmers or KTH but also at ABB. Sida funds will be disbursed to Chalmers and KTH\, for supervison etc\, however\, no Sida funds will be transferred to ABB. The students will get subsistence allowance while in Sweden - at Chalmers\, KTH or ABB.,Addis Abeba University har ansökt om stöd från Sida uppgående till 196 000 000 SEK för programmet "Support to Research Training and Capacity Building at Addis AbebaUniversity 2018-2023".Målet med insatsen är att stärka kapaciteten för högre utbildning och forskning i Etiopien och därmed bidra till landets strategi för fattigdomsminskning genom att stödja  forskarutbildning och forskning vid Addis AbebaUniversity och att utveckla och erbjuda multidisciplinära forskarutbildningar i alla för landets utveckling relevanta områden. Insatsen har följande specifika målsättningar:- Att starta och genomföra "in-house" forskarutbildningar\,- Att stärka universitetets forskningskapacitet\,- Att införa automatiserade system för egendomsförvaltning\, upphandling och personaladministration samt registrering av studenter\,- Att stödja akademiska och administrativa reformer\,- Att stärka samverkan med privat näringsliv och tekniköverföring\,- Att förbättra bibilioteksservice och stärka möjligheter för forskarutbildning inom såväl pågående som planerade doktorandprogram.Insatsen består av två delar\, a) forskningsinfrastruktur\, forskningsförvaltning och forskning vid AAU\, och b) institutionssamarbete mellan AAU och svenska universitet.Den första delen omfattar stöd till Information and Communication Technology (ICT)\, bibliotek\, kvalitetssäkring\, kontakter med privata näringslivet och tekniköverföring\, gender-kontoret\, handledarutbildning och gender-frågor\, stöd till "Sida Projects Co-ordination Office" liksom stöd till AAU´s forskarutbildningsprogram - besökande handledare och examinatorer samt etiopiska doktoranders vistelser utanför Etiopien. Även stöd till tematisk forskning\, till 5 forskningsanslag att utlysas i konkurrens.Den andra delen omfattar institutionssamarbete inom fyra områden; jämförande internationell pedagogik\, företags- och nationalekonomi\, bioteknik och elektroteknik.Svenska universitet som deltar i samarbetet är Göteborgs universitet\, Jönköping University och Göteborgs universitet\, Sveriges Lantbruksuniversitet samt Chalmers och KTH.Insatsens totala budget är 196 000 000 SEK\, den totala budgeten för den första delen är ca 45 700 000 SEK och för den andra delen ca 142 700 00 SEK. Därutöver\, ca 4 600 000 SEK till Uppsala universitet/International Science Program (ISP) för koordinering av svenska universitet samt 3 000 000 SEK som behålls av Sida för oförutsedda utgifter som t ex utvärderingar\, gender-aktiviteter\, handledarutbildning\, utbildningsinsatser etc.Avtalsstrukten har fyra nivåer av avtal (medel reflekteras i komponenterna):A) Avtal mellan Sverige och Addis Abeba University\, som omfattar alla medel i insatsen. Ingen vidareförmedlning av medel från AAU till tredje part\,B) Avtal mellan Sida och Uppsala universitet/International Science Program (ISP) om koordinering av utbetalning av medel till svenska universitet\,C) ISP kommer att skriva avtal med 5 svenska universitet avseende institutionssamarbete inom fyra områden. Dessa avtal reglerar medelsöverföring till svenska universitet\, baserat på årliga av Sida godkända arbetsplaner och budgetar. Avtalen reglerar även vetenskaplig och finansiell rapportering samt revisioner av de svenska samarbetsparterna.D) Uppehållsbidrag för etiopiska doktorander vid vistelse i Sverige regleras av insats 54100045 mellan Uppsala universitet/ISP och Sida.Utöver dessa avtal om medelsflöde har samtliga svenska universitet ett "Memorandum of Understanding"/avtal med AAU. ISP har inte ett eget MoU med AAU. Huruvida ett sådant behövs eller inte kommer att avgöras under insatsens första år\, i dalog med parterna.Inom institutionssamarbetet i elektroteknik kommer etiopiska doktorander att tillbringa viss tid i Sverige som en del av doktorandutbildningen - vid Chalmers eller KTH men även vid ABB i Ludvika/Västerås. Sida-medel kommer att utbetalas till Chalmers och KTH\, t ex ersättning för handledning\, men inga Sida-medel kommer att överföras till ABB. De etiopiska studenterna kommer att\, när de vistas i Sverige vid Chalmers\, KTH eller ABB\, erhålla uppehållsbidrag.All rapportering - vetenskaplig\, finansiell\, revision\, ska godkännas av ambassaden i Addis Abeba.,The objective of the intervention is to:
“Strengthen higher education\, research training and research in Ethiopia\, through support to Addis Abeba University”
 At the end of the intervention a strengthened research environment at AAU is expected\, to be achieved through structured\, collaborative\, institutional co-operation programmes with Swedish universities. They are all to some degree a combination of Swedish co-supervisors\, strategic exposure to Swedish research environments for Ethiopian supervisors\, Ph.D. students and researchers\, training and classes at AAU by key Swedish personnel and researchers\, establishment of a sound research tradition by systematically working towards deadlines and results and support to infrastructure and scientific materials and equipment required to conduct research at AAU.
In addition it is expected that the research management at AAU and functions of key value to a university\, such as the capacity of the library and ICT systems\, to have increased by directed support to those functions - also including a dialogue on less dependency on Sida and increased AAU funding for these core functions. In this way the intervention will affect the institutions at AAU as well as individuals at AAU – staff\, academic as well as administrative\, and MSc- and PhD-students. In addition the support to the gender office will create a more inclusive\, and empowering\, environment for all.
The main objective will to some extent\, and in the long run\, benefit also regional universities throughout the country since many of the graduated students are expected to return to the regional universities from where they were accepted.

column108: Gender Equality,Aid to Environment,Participatory Development/Good Governance,Trade Development,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation,Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification,Reproductive\, Maternal\, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH),Disaster Risk Reduction(DRR),Disability
column200:
This is the first period of the new agreement with AAU. The agreement was signed July 7 2018 and the first disbursement was made\, slightly delayed\, in September. 
The first annual planning meeting (APM) was held in November 2018 and was a kind of kick-off for the program. It was a very interesting event where\, for the first time\, many Swedish and Ethiopian stakeholders\, both researchers and administrators\, were together and could get an understanding of the collaboration. All tough not many changes\, compared to the proposal was anticipated\, the embassy still wanted to run the full cycle of submission and approval of plans and budgets in accordance to the agreement. There were no updated plans were submitted before the meeting (drafts should be submitted four weeks before the APM) and it took a very long time to received the final\, complete documents. The final 2018/19 plans did reflect some changes\, but not realistically compared to the delays of the programme. In this process\, many lessons were learnt for the next APM in May 2019\, which was also part of the purpose of the 2018 APM.
The second APM was held in May 2019. For this meeting plans and budgets were submitted ahead of the meeting\, but very late: soft copy on a Saturday three days ahead of the meeting and hard copies on the day of the meeting. However\, only budgets were submitted and they were not all compleate\, or they were not the latest versions as submitted to the SPCO. At the meeting sometimes other plans\, compared to those submitted to the embassy\, were presented.
As the plans for 2018/19 were not complete and approved at the time of the second APM\, we ended up in an unfortunate situation with many parallel dialogues. On top of this a lot of work also went into finalizing the old agreement\, and the final audit is still not initiated.
One result of the collaboration is also that all students have been admitted to the new programs according to plan\, and all other (except the unfotunte eight in economics) have a reported high level of engagement with their Swedish (and Ethiopian) supervisors. Many trips to Sweden (both students and AAU researchers) have been reported and several of the Swedish supervisors and researcher have vissited AAU (and many have visited the embassy). 
Despite the challenge with eight students in economics\, a handfull of students from the previous program with JIBS have graduated. The first ever AAU phd-graduate in management defended his thesis in May 2019.

Enhance scientific research\, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries\, in particular developing countries\, including\, by 2030\, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.

column200:
This is the first period of the new agreement with AAU. The agreement was signed July 7 2018 and the first disbursement was made\, slightly delayed\, in September. 
The first annual planning meeting (APM) was held in November 2018 and was a kind of kick-off for the program. It was a very interesting event where\, for the first time\, many Swedish and Ethiopian stakeholders\, both researchers and administrators\, were together and could get an understanding of the collaboration. All tough not many changes\, compared to the proposal was anticipated\, the embassy still wanted to run the full cycle of submission and approval of plans and budgets in accordance to the agreement. There were no updated plans were submitted before the meeting (drafts should be submitted four weeks before the APM) and it took a very long time to received the final\, complete documents. The final 2018/19 plans did reflect some changes\, but not realistically compared to the delays of the programme. In this process\, many lessons were learnt for the next APM in May 2019\, which was also part of the purpose of the 2018 APM.
The second APM was held in May 2019. For this meeting plans and budgets were submitted ahead of the meeting\, but very late: soft copy on a Saturday three days ahead of the meeting and hard copies on the day of the meeting. However\, only budgets were submitted and they were not all compleate\, or they were not the latest versions as submitted to the SPCO. At the meeting sometimes other plans\, compared to those submitted to the embassy\, were presented.
As the plans for 2018/19 were not complete and approved at the time of the second APM\, we ended up in an unfortunate situation with many parallel dialogues. On top of this a lot of work also went into finalizing the old agreement\, and the final audit is still not initiated.
One result of the collaboration is also that all students have been admitted to the new programs according to plan\, and all other (except the unfotunte eight in economics) have a reported high level of engagement with their Swedish (and Ethiopian) supervisors. Many trips to Sweden (both students and AAU researchers) have been reported and several of the Swedish supervisors and researcher have vissited AAU (and many have visited the embassy). 
Despite the challenge with eight students in economics\, a handfull of students from the previous program with JIBS have graduated. The first ever AAU phd-graduate in management defended his thesis in May 2019.

column17: UNODC (2014-2019) Criminal Justice - Nat Integr Progr for ETI Sub Prog. 2,UNODC (2014-2019) Criminal Justice - Nat Integr Progr for ETI Sub Prog. 2
column20:
The present proposal falls under Sub-Programme 2 of the National Integrated Programme on Criminal Justice and Integrity\, with a focus on strengthening the criminal justice system in Ethiopia. It is based on an assessment of the criminal justice system in Ethiopia which was undertaken by UNODC in 2011 following a request by the GoE. This assessment identified various areas that need to be addressed to support the Government’s reform efforts towards an effective and efficient criminal justice system\, including the proposed interventions on strengthening justice for children (Outcome 6) and enhancing legal aid/access to justice (Outcome 7).

An efficient\, accessible and fair justice system is essential for good governance\, upholding the rule of law and establishing a stable and predictable environment for investments\, economic growth and poverty reduction. The sub-programme on criminal justice and integrity of the National Integrated Programme for Ethiopia (NPE) seeks to strengthen the rule of law through the prevention of crime and the promotion of fair\, humane and accountable criminal justice system. To do this\, UNODC will assist and provide expertise to the Government of Ethiopia in developing an effective and responsible National Crime Prevention Strategy and Action Plan and to build the capacity of their criminal justice systems to operate more effectively within the framework of the rule of law\, while promoting human rights and protecting vulnerable groups. Based on UNODC’s NPE\, and in line with UNODC’s Regional Programme for Eastern Africa (2009-2015).,Ett effektivt\, tillgängligt och rättvist rättssystem är essentiellt för god samhällsstyrning\, genom att upprätthålla lagefterlevnad och etablera en stabil och förutsäglig miljö för investerare\, ekonomisk tillväxt och fattigdomsbekämpning. Delprogrammet rörande det straffrättsliga systemet och det Nationella Integrerade Programmet för Etiopiens (NPE) integritet ämnar stärka lagefterlevnaden genom att förebygga brott och att främja ett rättvist\, humant och ansvarskyldigt straffrättsligt system. För att göra detta kommer UNODC att assistera och delge expertis till Etiopiens regering angående att utveckla en effektiv och ansvarsfull Nationell Brottsförebyggande Strategi och tillvägagångsplan. De kommer också att hjälpa till med kapacitetsutveckling av det straffrättsliga systemet så att det ska verka effektivare inom en rättstat\, medan det främjar mänskliga rättigheter och skyddar utsatta samhällsgrupper. Sverige har beslutat\, baserat på UNODC:s NPE och i linje med UNODC:s Regionala Program för Östafrika (2009-2015)\, att stödja de två nedanstående resultat inom NPE. Stödet utgår under de kommande tre åren och uppgår till totalt 12 MSEK. Utav dessa 12 MSEK kommer 2 MSEK att utbetalas 2014\, 5 MSEK 2015 och 5 MSEK 2016. 

1.Rättvisa för barn
UNODC resultat 6: Etiopiens regering antar program för förbättrat skydd av barn som brutit mot lagen
2.Rättshjälp
UNODC resultat 7: Etiopiens regering utökar program för förbättrad tillgång till rättssystemet för hjälpbehövande\, speciellt utsatta och övriga riskgrupper. 
.,The overall objective of this sub-programme is to support the GoE’s justice reform efforts towards an effective and efficient criminal justice system to improve effectiveness\, accessibility\, accountability\, transparency and fairness of the justice system.

column200: One of the main achievements of UNODC is in relation to developing capacities\, prison training has been traditionally focused on security issues but UNODC has made it possible to include human rights and international conventions standards. The adoption of the international minimum standard of treatment of prisoners\, Nelson Mandela Rules is an achievement on its own.UNODCs support to the Child Justice Project of the Federal Supreme Court was highly relevant in a context where many programs of support for vulnerable women and children that had been running for up to 15 years had been discontinued. The number of child friendly benches in courts\, which include video and audio equipment to avoid physical contact between victims and perpetrators had fallen from over 100 to only one but with UNODCs assistance this has increased to eight. At least six important pieces of legislation in the criminal justice sector were developed with the help of UNODC in recent years. Some of these draft legislation\, including those on federal prisons and human trafficking were subsequently adopted by the Federal Parliament\, while the enactment of others\, such as the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code is still pending. It is important to note that the Federal Prisons Proclamation is limited to the 6 federal prisons of the country and there is a need to cascade the prison reform in the regional states\, where more than 90% of the countrys prisons are found. The past seven years of implementation of the program led to the sustained engagement with the various stakeholders of the criminal justice sector. Moreover\, UNODC has improved its coordination\, under the UN team to co-chair the Justice Working group with UNDP. Through this support\, UNODC was able to establish ICT centre at the prison training centre\, at the Federal Police University\, Federal Justice Professionals Training Center\, and at Amhara regional level prison. Beneficiaries have been introduced to the known UNODC Global e-learning modules and they have already received their corresponding certifications in different topics including Alternatives to Imprisonment for Women Offenders and the Nelson Mandela Rules.Sweden's deep dive analysis on institutional building of some of its contributions have relieved that UNODC's staff have built strong relationship with key interlocutors within the government. As such\, embedding consulting staff within what has been traditionally known as 'sensitive' government bodies\, has been appreciated. Moreover\, UNODC has been appreciated for its efforts of contextualizing and tailoring to local needs various international standards for ease of domestication and implementation.

column17: ECCSA PSD Hub Fas III (2015-2020),ECCSA PSD Hub Phase III (2015-2020)
column20: Insatsen är en uppföljning på\, och avrunding av\, tidigare stöd till det etiopiska kammarsystemet genom "PSD Hub". Huvudmålet med kammarsystemets främjande av ett förbättrat näringsklimat har under samtliga faser varit en stärkt tillväxtprocess som även fattiga människor kan bidra till och dra nytta av. Tidigare faser\, som under åtta år av tio hade Addis-kammaren som värd\, var inriktade först på etablering av en kapacitetshöjande facilitet och en plattform för policypåverkan\, "advocacy" för ett bättre näringsklimat på den nationella arenan\, och sedan på konsolidering av det arbetet. I slutet av den andra fasen krävde lokala myndigheter att navet i främjandearbetet\, den alltmer framgångsrika dialogplattformen PPCF (Public Private Consultation Forum)\, inrättades hos den nationella kammaren ECCSA. Den tredje fas av stöd som här föreslås\, inriktas på att konsolidera ECCSA i sin relativt nya roll som dialognav\, samt på att stärka deras kapacitet att uppfylla sin potential som övergripande paraplyorganisation för näringslivets aktörer i Etiopien. Detta med fokus på att främja hållbarheten i deras arbete\, finansiellt likväl som socialt och miljömässigt. Insatsens totala storlek är på USD 6 693 000\, varav Sida föreslås betala USD 5 900 000. Stödet är utformat så att gåvomedel avtar i takt med att kapacitetsutvecklingne ger effekt och egna medel kan tillföras i ökande utsträckning. Målet är att ECCSA finansierar minst hälften av sina egna operationella kostnader efter den fem år långa insatsen\, samtidigt som en plattform och kapacitet etableras som medger ECCSA att bli fullständigt självfinansierade år 2025.,ECCSA PSD Hub Phase III is an extension of earlier cooperation with the Ethiopian Chamber system within ECCSA. The support objective is   to contribute to economic development of Ethiopia\, by improved entrepreneurial environment though strengthened capacity of the local private sector to constructively contribute to the national dialogue  on economic development. Focus sustainability.\n\n[Transfer text incomplete.],The over-arching goal of this intervention is to "Contribute to inclusive economic growth in Ethiopia by creating a positive enabling business environment for private sector development". This goal is expected to be achieved through realization of the following objective of the intervention. "Effective public-private dialogue that leads to regulatory and policy changes; resulting in a more conducive environment for sustainable and inclusive economic growth."Outcomes are expected in two core intervention areas within the programme\, "Strengthened Ethiopian chamber system that functions as a strategic representative and viable entity facilitating consultation with the government on private sector needs for inclusive growth" and "Chamber system is financially sustainable and is responsive to the needs and demands of members and businesses".

column17: Centre for Human Rights\, stöd till strategisk plan,Centre for Human Rights\, 2017-2021\, Support to Strategic plan
column20: Support to the Centre for Human Rights at the Addis Abeba University and its Strategic Plan 2016-20. The support is made in collaboration with Norway.,Finansiellt stöd och samarbete med The Human Rights Center vid Addis Abeba Universitet i syfte att stärka utbildning och forsking inom området mänskliga rättigheter. Samarbete mellan Raoul Wallenberg Institute (RWI) och AAU-CHR\, inom CHR utbildning\, juridisk hjälp och forsking,The proposed interventions goal is to contribute to the long term goal of ensuring respect for the human rights of all Ethiopians.The activities under this Sub-Project focus mainly on the academic programs of CHR and are aimed to:1.Design and launch new multidisciplinary post graduate level academic programs on any two issues such as on child rights and protection\, on good governance and human rights\, on migration\, and other fields of multidisciplinary studies in human rights;2.Strengthen CHRs capabilities of delivering multidisciplinary programs in human rights education through the production of pertinent textbooks and manuals;3.Organize short term training courses on various human rights issues focused on the strategic thematic areas targeting high and mid-level government and civil society leaders and officials.

column200:
Below is a summary of the main achievements in 2019:
- Developing an interdisciplinary MA curriculum on the Rights of Children:The curriculum for MA in Children’s Rights and Childhood Studies has been finalizedaccording to the work plan. Though the curriculum is finalized\, the formal process forapproval of the curriculum and the launch of the program are still pending. Note:Follow-up needed on how the process is progressing towards the final launch of theprogram.- Developing curriculum for MA program on good governance and human rights:This activity will not be implemented due to a new rule in the University that does notencourage the development of new curricula. Note: follow-up on the reallocation of thebudget line.
- Training 1: Human Rights of Internally Displaced Persons- Training 2: Media Freedom and Human Rights
Both the trainings have been conducted as per the workplan. The immediate resultsachieved through these trainings could be seen through training evaluationquestionnaires however changes in attitude and behaviour will take time to assess andrequired in-depth monitoring process.
- Textbooks and teaching material on “Human Rights and the Administration ofCriminal Justice” and “Local Governance and Human Rights” are in the process of beenprepared. Delay in implementation has been explained in the report.
- This year\, CHR organized a policy dialogue forum on a theme “Confronting the Pastand Building the Future: Promises of Transitional Justice in Ethiopia”. This is a timelyand pertinent topic; the forum has been well attended and constructive/informativediscussions have been held. The actual result in change in behaviour/attitude is yet to beassessed. Note: Follow-up needed on whether the brief has been prepared and disseminated.
- Organizing Networking and Experience Sharing Workshop - on legal aid in universities- done- Grant were given for three universities: Jimma\, Mekelle and Debreberhan. The granthave been mostly used to provide legal aid services. The legal aid services provided asdescribed in the report have been successful in providing access to justice to vulnerablegroups.
The same is true for the legal aid service provided by the legal aid centres established bythis project in 5 project areas. CHR has managed to provide free legal services to 8\,033individuals. Through the services rendered by CHR\, women\, children\, persons withdisabilities\, workers\, migrants and other vulnerable groups have used legal andadministrative remedies to seek redress for violations of their rights.
The legal aid provision centers of CHR provide legal aid services which include advice; referral and information; preparation of statement of claim\, statement of defense and memorandumof appeal; court representation; and preparation of other administrative applications andpleadings.
In the reporting period\, as result of services rendered (i.e. preparation of pleadings andcourt representation) by CHR\, 2\,209 cases were instituted before judicial body. Inaddition\, CHR also prepared 1\,055 administrative applications and pleadings broughtbefore local administrative bodies by beneficiaries of the legal aid provision centers.Moreover\, there are several cases with successful outcomes. Some of the success storiesare provided in the narrative report.
- Two CHR PhD students were sent on study tour of one month to University of Graz tobring international experiences and improve their skills. During their stay in Graz\, thestudents worked on their dissertation proposal with the assistance of professors assignedby the host institution. In addition\, CHR has also selected 4 PhD and 2 MA students tobe sent on similar study tour to Lund University.
- CHR has hosted two international scholars from Belgium and USA as per this year’splan. These scholars taught PhD courses among other things.
- One international visiting researcher from South Africa was selected and allpreparation was completed.
- The CHR provided tailor-made training for officials of local government agencies inthe six sites who will facilitate the works of community rights promoters by providingforums and the necessary support and endorsement.Topics covered during the trainingwere introduction to human rights\, women’s rights\, children’s rights\, workers’ rights andrights of persons with disabilities.
- Various training to community rights promoters has been carried out during thereporting period. CHR has 139 (31 in Addis Ababa\, 27 in Adama\, 25 in Ambo\, 14 inDebre Birhan\, 18 in Hawass and 24 in Semera) community rights promoters who areactively engaging in awareness raising campaigns\, preparing simple pleadings\, serving aslinks between the legal aid centers and their communities and distributing promotionalmaterials to their communities. Summary of activities undertaken by community rightspromoters from December 2018 to November 2019 is provided in the narrativereport.
As highlighted above\, the CHR has carried out important activities as per the workplan.The reporting period has been a good year for the Centre in terms of implementation ofplanned activities.
As most activities focus on training and awareness raising\, it is difficultto assess the end result without carrying out a more thorough monitoring. However\, theresult achieved through the legal aid service in terms of providing vulnerable groupsaccess to justice are impressive and need to be encouraged.
It is assessed that the project is on the right track. It is to be noted that the good pace thatthe Centre has maintained in 2019 has been interrupted by Covid-19 (in 2020) and therewill be a need to have a no cost extension of the program.
Collaboration between RWI and CHRNote:It is to be noted that the partnership between RWI and CHR has not been smooth sincethe beginning of the project. The two institutions together with Sida held a tripartitediscussion to address the underlying issues that are negatively affecting the partnership.The minutes of meeting of the discussion is hereby attached. The points that need followup are the following:
- Follow up on Mid-term evaluation of the collaboration between RWI and CHR. Thecurrent mid-term evaluation has not been accepted by the CHR. It has been agreed tocarry out another mid-term evaluation by a neutral consultant and TOR for theevaluation should be agreed by all stakehoders.
- Need to discuss and revisit the needs of the centre (in terms of capacity building) andelaborate on how the collaboration between the Centre and RWI could be amendedbased on the identified needs. The initially agreed upon workplan should be a livingdocument that serves as guiding document but which is subject to revision.
- The narrative and financial report for 2019 for the collaboration with RWI and thecomments given by the Centre is attached in Trac.

column17: Danida Sustainable Infrastructure Finance (DSIF) - Ethiopia - Assela Wind Farm Project
column20: The project will provide affordable clean energy through construction of a 100MW wind farm\, approximately 150 km south of Addis Ababa\, delivering on average 330 GWh of electricity a year. The project will contribute to the Government of Ethiopia’s goal of increasing renewable energy generation capacity\, diversifying the energy mix and increasing access to electricity for the Ethiopian population. The energy sector is based almost entirely on hydropower\, making the country vulnerable to long periods of drought because of climate changes in the region. By introducing other green energy sources\, the GoE wants to establish an energy mix that will sustain development. Besides the wind farm\, the project includes technical assistance and training of staff.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: Upgrading Women's Food Product Value Chains in Northern Ethiopia,Amélioration des chaînes de valeur de la production alimentaire par les femmes dans le nord de l'Éthiopie
column20:
Promoting agricultural product value chains and linking farmers to markets are key strategies in Ethiopia's efforts to fight poverty and improve food security. However\, many of these initiatives fail to integrate women's products and priorities into value chain development. This research project will help rural women in remote areas of Tigray in northern Ethiopia improve their income and household food security by identifying and promoting innovative strategies that will upgrade value chains for local food products and help women better access markets. The project will focus on local pulse crops\, such as lentils\, faba beans\, and chickpeas and evaluate opportunities for commercialization and to upgrade traditional food product value chains. The project will explore income potential for women for these foods\, while strengthening and leveraging the activities of women's cooperatives. By improving women's access to markets and incomes\, the project will not only result in the economic empowerment of women\, but will also boost household food security and welfare. Results will inform policy and development interventions in Ethiopia on how rural women in remote areas can participate more effectively in local and national markets.,La promotion des chaînes de valeur des produits agricoles et l'établissement de liens entre les agriculteurs et les marchés comptent parmi les principales stratégies mises en oeuvre par l'Éthiopie pour lutter contre la pauvreté et accroître la sécurité alimentaire. Toutefois\, bon nombre de ces initiatives omettent d'intégrer la production et les priorités des femmes au développement des chaînes de valeur.

Ce projet de recherche aidera les femmes des régions rurales éloignées du Tigray\, dans le nord de l'Éthiopie\, à améliorer leurs revenus et la sécurité alimentaire de leur ménage en définissant et en mettant en avant des stratégies novatrices qui amélioreront les chaînes de valeur des produits alimentaires locaux et faciliteront l'accès des femmes aux marchés.

Le projet accordera la priorité aux légumineuses à graines telles que les lentilles\, les féveroles et les pois chiches; on évaluera aussi les possibilités de commercialisation de ces légumineuses et d'amélioration des chaînes de valeur des produits alimentaires traditionnels. On tentera de déterminer dans quelle mesure les femmes pourraient tirer un revenu de ces produits\, tout en renforçant les coopératives de femmes et en tirant le meilleur parti possible de leurs activités.

En améliorant l'accès des femmes aux marchés de même que leurs revenus\, le projet favorisera l'autonomisation économique des femmes en plus d'accroître la sécurité alimentaire et le bien-être des ménages.

Les résultats éclaireront les interventions sur le plan des politiques et du développement en Éthiopie quant aux moyens que peuvent prendre les femmes des régions rurales éloignées pour intervenir de façon plus efficace sur les marchés locaux et nationaux.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: Adaptation to Increase Resilience to Climate Change in Ethiopian Agriculture,Favoriser l'adaptation afin d'accroître la résilience de l'agriculture éthiopienne face aux changements climatiques
column20:
Ethiopia's agriculture sector contributes 42 to 45% of its gross domestic product and employs more than 80% of the population. However\, the sector remains fragile and vulnerable to climate change. This project will provide knowledge to help Ethiopians adapt. Climate change and agriculture in Ethiopia Scientists are predicting that rainfall in Ethiopia will be more variable\, with more drought- and flood-related incidents in the future. Projected rainfall changes will make Ethiopia even more vulnerable to harvest and food shortfalls. Small-scale farmers will need to adopt water management technologies to increase food output in the face of a changing climate. There is a need to identify the barriers that farmers face. Enhancing adaptation through research This project aims to enhance the adaptation process in Ethiopia by -analyzing combinations of technologies for profitability and ease of use; -identifying barriers for optimal adaptation by examining data from the Blue Nile Basin that has a focus on climate change in small-scale agriculture; and -conducting a randomized controlled trial of a policy intervention designed to improve adaptation options that are socially accepted. The project team will also investigate how gender differentiated ime and risk preferences affect whether and to what extent households adopt technology. Results will help government and farmers The researchers will share their evidence-based analysis with the Ethiopian Ministries of Agriculture\, and Water\, Irrigation and Energy. The findings are expected to inform ongoing government policies and programs designed to increase adoption rates\, crop yields\, food security\, sustainable agricultural growth\, and resilience in the face of climate change. Programs include the Climate Resilient Green Economy Strategy and the second phase of the Sustainable Land Management Sector Program. The project will build skills and knowledge among younger researchers\, such as postdoctoral\, PhD\, and postgraduate students. The team will train farmers and extension agents\, who educate farmers in new innovations. Research outputs will include scientific peer-reviewed publications\, technical reports\, and policy briefs.,Le secteur de l'agriculture représente de 42 à 45 % du produit intérieur brut de l'Éthiopie et occupe plus de 80 % de la population du pays. Il demeure toutefois fragile et vulnérable aux effets des changements climatiques. Le présent projet fournira des connaissances qui aideront les Éthiopiens à s'adapter.

Les changements climatiques et l'agriculture en Éthiopie
Les scientifiques prédisent que la pluviosité se fera plus variable en Éthiopie\, et que les épisodes de sécheresse et d'inondation seront plus nombreux dans les années à venir. Les variations prévues des précipitations rendront l'Éthiopie encore plus vulnérable aux récoltes insuffisantes et aux pénuries alimentaires.

Les petits exploitants agricoles devront adopter des techniques de gestion de l'eau afin d'accroître leur production en dépit des changements climatiques. Il faut donc déterminer quels obstacles ils auront à surmonter. 

Favoriser l'adaptation par la recherche
L'équipe du présent projet a pour but de consolider le processus d'adaptation en Éthiopie : 
- en analysant diverses combinaisons de techniques sur le plan de la rentabilité et de la facilité d'utilisation;
- en déterminant ce qui fait obstacle à une adaptation optimale par l'examen des données provenant du bassin du Nil Bleu qui concernent les effets des changements climatiques sur l'agriculture à petite échelle;
- en effectuant l'essai comparatif avec répartition aléatoire d'une intervention en matière de politiques visant à améliorer les mesures d'adaptation possibles qui sont socialement acceptées. 

L'équipe du projet étudiera aussi de quelle façon les préférences sexospécifiques relatives au temps et au risque influencent la décision que prennent les ménages d'adopter ou non les nouvelles techniques\, et la mesure dans laquelle ils le font le cas échéant.

Les résultats vont aider le gouvernement et les exploitants agricoles
Les chercheurs communiqueront leur analyse fondée sur des données probantes au ministère de l'Agriculture et au ministère de l'Eau\, de l'Irrigation et de l'Énergie de l'Éthiopie. Les constatations devraient éclairer les politiques et les programmes gouvernementaux actuels qui visent à accroître les taux d'adoption des nouvelles techniques\, le rendement des cultures\, la sécurité alimentaire et la résilience face aux changements climatiques\, de même qu'à stimuler la croissance agricole durable. Les programmes ciblés comprennent la Climate Resilient Green Economy Strategy et la deuxième phase du Sustainable Land Management Sector Program.

Le projet renforcera les compétences et les connaissances de jeunes chercheurs\, notamment d'étudiants postdoctoraux\, d'étudiants au doctorat et d'étudiants diplômés. L'équipe donnera une formation aux exploitants agricoles et aux agents de vulgarisation\, qui sont chargés de faire connaître les innovations aux agriculteurs. Les extrants de recherche comprendront des articles dans des revues scientifiques à comité de lecture\, des rapports techniques et des notes d'analyse.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: Migration\, Remittances\, and Forest Dependence in Ethiopia: Implications for Food Security\, Gender\, and Forest Conservation,Migration\, envois d'argent et dépendance à l'égard des forêts en Éthiopie
column20:
This project will provide evidence that offers important insight into the connection between migration\, gender\, and forest dependence in rural Ethiopia. Need for labour migration\, forest resources While most rural households rely on agriculture for their livelihood\, many poor households in developing countries use labour migration and forest resources to improve their welfare. Existing research offers simplistic assumptions that migration invariably leads to deforestation in the tropics\, and that forest recovery is always a consequence of people leaving rural areas. These assumptions are being questioned\, particularly as researchers analyze and document the complex factors that influence migration outcomes. As a result\, it is not clear whether labour migration complements\, or serves as a substitute\, for forest product extraction by migrant-sending households. Furthermore\, whether and how labour migration influences intra-household gender relations\, food security\, and forest dependence at the places of origin is unclear. Insights into the effects on households The Ethiopian Economic Association/Ethiopian Economic Policy Research Institute (EEA-EEPRI) will collaborate with the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR) on this project. They will explore the effects of migration and remittances on household forest dependence\, food security\, and intra-household gender division of work. Researchers will investigate the degree to which those effects vary across different migration types (for example\, domestic versus international migration\, and rural versus urban) and across socio-economic groups and locations. A better understanding of these issues is of crucial importance in Ethiopia for a number of reasons. The government has formulated and implemented specific policies on gender\, forestry\, and food security. However\, the ways in which rural out-migration is influencing the achievement of gender equity\, forest conservation\, and rural food security goals are not well understood. This research will aim to propose options for policymakers and development partners. Project leadership This project is made possible through the Think Tank Initiative (TTI). TTI is a multi-funder program dedicated to strengthening independent policy research institutions\, or think tanks\, in developing countries. The program aims to enhance their ability to provide sound research that informs and influences policy.,Ce projet fournira des éléments probants qui permettent de mieux comprendre les liens qui existent entre la migration\, la sexospécificité et la dépendance à l'égard des forêts dans les régions rurales de l'Éthiopie.

Nécessité de la migration des travailleurs\, des ressources de la forêt
Même si la majorité des ménages en milieu rural comptent sur l'agriculture pour leur subsistance\, de nombreux ménages pauvres dans les pays en développement ont recours à la migration des travailleurs et aux ressources de la forêt pour améliorer leur bien-être. Les recherches actuelles offrent des hypothèses simplistes à savoir que la migration entraîne invariablement la déforestation dans les tropiques\, et que la régénération des forêts est toujours une conséquence du départ des populations rurales. 

Ces hypothèses sont remises en question et les chercheurs tentent plus particulièrement d'analyser et de documenter les facteurs complexes qui influencent la migration. Avec pour résultat qu'il n'est pas toujours clair si la migration des travailleurs contribue à l'extraction des produits de la forêt par les ménages d'où sont partis les travailleurs migrants\, ou si elle agit comme un moyen de substitution. De plus\, il n'est pas possible d'établir si et en quoi la migration des travailleurs influence les relations entre hommes et femmes à l'intérieur des ménages\, la sécurité alimentaire\, et la dépendance à l'égard des forêts dans les lieux d'origine.

Aperçus des effets sur les ménages
L'Ethiopian Economic Association/Ethiopian Economic Policy Research Institute (EEA-EEPRI) collaborera avec le Centre pour la recherche forestière internationale (CIFOR) sur ce projet. Ils examineront les effets de la migration et des envois d'argent sur la dépendance des ménages sur la forêt\, la sécurité alimentaire et la division sexospécifique des tâches dans les ménages. 

Les chercheurs tenteront de déterminer dans quelle mesure ces effets varient selon les divers types de migration (par exemple\, migration dans le pays par rapport à migration à l'étranger\, et migration rurale par rapport à migration urbaine) et selon les groupes socioéconomiques et endroits.

Une meilleure compréhension de ces questions est d'une importance capitale en Éthiopie pour diverses raisons. Le gouvernement a formulé et mis en oeuvre des politiques particulières sur la différence entre les hommes et les femmes\, la foresterie et la sécurité alimentaire. Cependant\, la manière dont la migration à l'extérieur des régions rurales influence la réalisation de l'équité entre les sexes\, la conservation de la forêt\, et la sécurité alimentaire en milieu rural n'est pas bien comprise.

Cette recherche tentera de proposer des solutions aux décideurs et aux partenaires en matière de développement.

Direction du projet
Ce projet est rendu possible dans le cadre de l'initiative Think Tank (ITT). L'ITT est un programme financé par plusieurs bailleurs de fonds qui vise à renforcer les capacités des institutions indépendantes vouées à la recherche sur les politiques\, ou think tanks\, dans les pays en développement. L'objectif est d'améliorer la capacité des think tanks à effectuer des recherches rigoureuses\, susceptibles d'éclairer et d'influencer les politiques.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: Statistical alliance for vital events: Strengthening reporting & program uses of facility-based child & maternal mortality,Alliance statistique pour les faits d’état civil : renforcer le recours aux programmes d’enregistrement des décès de mères et d’enfants
column20:
Most deaths in sub-Saharan Africa occur without medical attention\, and as a result\, the causes of death (COD) remain unknown. This lack of information greatly limits evidence-based planning and slows progress in the attainment of health targets\, including those related to maternal and child health. To address this\, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the enhancement of both community and facility-based reporting of COD. The WHO also emphasizes the crucial need of integrating COD data within health information management systems and civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) systems\, and ensuring that the data is used by health ministries and disease control programs. 

This project aims to improve facility-based reporting of COD data in Ethiopia and Mozambique by training doctors and hospital administrators on the use of simple electronic systems for capturing COD reliably\, and promoting the use of the data to improve policies and programs for maternal and child health. By complementing efforts to strengthen community-based reporting of CODs in an ongoing maternal and child health project\, this project will demonstrate the feasibility of implementing the WHO recommendations on the generation and use of comprehensive\, high-quality COD data in health policy and program development. 

This initiative is building on an established partnership between the Statistical Alliance for Vital Events (St. Michaels Hospital\, Canada)\, the Ethiopia Public Health Association\, the Centro de Investigação em Saudé de Manhiça (Mozambique)\, and St. John’s Research Institute (India). The project is closely aligned with the Government of Canada’s prioritization of CRVS systems as a valuable public investment for safeguarding the rights of women and children\, improving policy development and program delivery for maternal and child health\, and strengthening accountability. The researchers will leverage opportunities for continued engagement with the Centre of Excellence for CRVS Systems housed at IDRC. This project is funded by the Innovating for Maternal and Child Health in Africa program. It is a seven-year CA$36 million initiative funded by Global Affairs Canada\, IDRC\, and the Canadian Institutes of Health Research.,Comme la majorité des décès en Afrique subsaharienne se produisent sans surveillance médicale\, les causes des décès demeurent inconnues. Ce manque d’information limite considérablement la planification fondée sur des données factuelles et compromet la réalisation des objectifs de santé\, y compris ceux liés à la santé maternelle et infantile. Pour y remédier\, l’Organisation mondiale de la Santé (OMS) recommande l’amélioration du mécanisme de détermination des causes de décès à la fois au sein de la communauté et au sein des structures de soins. L’OMS insiste également sur le besoin crucial d’intégrer les données sur les causes de décès dans les systèmes de gestion de l’information sur la santé et les systèmes d’établissement des statistiques de l’état civil et d’enregistrement des faits d’état civil\, de façon à ce que les données soient utilisées par les ministères de la Santé et les programmes de lutte contre les maladies. 

Ce projet consiste à améliorer la déclaration des données sur les causes des décès qui surviennent dans des établissements de santé en Éthiopie et au Mozambique\, en expliquant aux médecins et aux administrateurs d’hôpitaux comment tirer parti de ces données pour améliorer les politiques et les programmes qui ont une incidence sur la santé des mères et des enfants. En complétant les efforts déployés pour renforcer la communication des causes de décès survenus au sein de la communauté dans le cadre d’un projet permanent sur la santé maternelle et infantile\, ce projet mettra en évidence la faisabilité de l’application des recommandations émises par l’OMS sur la production et l’utilisation de données de haute qualité et exhaustives. 

Le projet s’inscrit dans la logique du gouvernement du Canada qui consiste à donner la priorité aux systèmes d’établissement des statistiques de l’état civil et d’enregistrement des faits d’état civil\, qui sont de formidables outils d’investissement public favorisant la protection des droits des femmes et des enfants\, l’amélioration de l’élaboration des politiques et de l’exécution des programmes axés sur la santé maternelle et infantile\, et le renforcement de la reddition de comptes. Ce projet est financé par l’initiative Innovation pour la santé des mères et des enfants d’Afrique. Cette initiative de 36 millions de CAD sur sept ans est financée conjointement par Affaires mondiales Canada\, le CRDI et les Instituts de recherche en santé du Canada.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: A comparative study of child marriage and parenthood in Ethiopia\, India\, Peru and Zambia,Étude comparative des mariages d’enfants et de la parentalité en Éthiopie\, en Inde\, au Pérou et en Zambie
column20:
The aim of this project is to enhance the understanding of the complexities of child marriage and parenthood to inform policies and programming. The project will generate new evidence of international relevance\, and by taking a comparative approach\, it will contribute to breaking the intergenerational cycles of poverty and gender inequality. Studies to date have emphasized the drivers and immediate consequences for mothers and their infants. By taking an approach that emphasizes life course poverty and gender inequality\, this project will help uncover how interventions in health\, education\, violence\, and livelihoods need to be adapted to meet the needs of adolescent parents or children who are married\, in order to have a positive effect on girls’ and boys’ trajectories.

The overall research will be led by Young Lives (University of Oxford). The research will be undertaken in collaboration with Child Frontiers (Zambia) and Grupo de Analisis para el Desarollo – GRADE (Peru). A socio-ecological life course perspective will guide the research\, which will use mixed methods\, including quantitative as well as participatory approaches. It will also use a relational approach to gender and generation\, examining the relationships\, power structures\, and norms and practices that influence adolescents’ and young people’s transitions\, not only in terms of motherhood and marriage but also with respect to boys\, marriage\, fatherhood\, and the formation of new households. To ensure uptake\, an innovative engagement plan will be developed that involves key stakeholders from the outset\, especially those drafting policies related to Sustainable Development Goal #5\, Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls.,Le but de ce projet consiste à améliorer la compréhension des complexités du mariage d’enfants et de la parentalité pour éclairer les politiques et les programmes. Ce projet produira de nouvelles données probantes de pertinence internationale et\, grâce à l’approche comparative adoptée\, il contribuera à briser le cycle intergénérationnel de la pauvreté et celui de l’inégalité entre les sexes. Les études réalisées à ce jour ont relevé les facteurs et les conséquences immédiates pour les mères et leurs bébés. En adoptant une approche qui souligne le niveau de pauvreté au cours d’une vie et l’inégalité entre les sexes\, ce projet pourra découvrir de quelle façon les interventions en matière de santé\, d’éducation\, de violence et de moyens de subsistance devront s’adapter pour satisfaire les besoins de parents adolescents ou d’enfants mariés afin d’avoir un effet positif sur la trajectoire des filles et des garçons.

La recherche globale sera menée par Young Lives de l’Université Oxford. Cette recherche sera menée en collaboration avec Child Frontiers (Zambie) et le Grupo de Analisis para el Desarollo ou GRADE (Pérou). La recherche sera orientée par la perspective socioécologique d’une vie entière et fera appel à des méthodes mixtes\, notamment des approches quantitatives et participatives. Les chercheurs mettront aussi en œuvre une approche relationnelle des genres et des générations\, et examineront ainsi les relations\, les structures de pouvoir et les normes et pratiques qui influent sur les transitions des adolescents et des jeunes en s’intéressant non seulement à la maternité et au mariage\, mais aussi aux garçons\, à leur mariage et à leur paternité\, ainsi qu’à la formation de nouveaux ménages. Pour assurer l’adoption\, un plan novateur visant à faire participer les parties prenantes clés dès le début sera développé\, y compris ceux qui rédigent les politiques relatives à l’objectif de développement durable no 5\, parvenir à l’égalité des sexes et à l’autonomisation de l’ensemble des femmes et des filles.

column15: International Development Research Centre,Centre de recherches pour le développement international,Centro Internacional de Investigaciones para el Desarrollo
column17: Centre of Excellence for CRVS Systems: The vulnerability of internally displaced women and children whose civil status is not registered in Ethiopia,Centre d’excellence sur les systèmes d’ESEC : Vulnérabilité des femmes et des enfants qui sont déplacés à l’intérieur de leur pays - Éthiopie
column20:
Emergencies and displacements create major challenges to the provision of effective civil registration services such as marriages\, births\, and deaths. Restoring registration activities and clearing backlogs after emergencies are often complex and costly undertakings requiring specific legal\, operational\, and policy provisions. Civil registration is a critical tool for protecting fundamental human rights and freedoms. When civil registration systems fail due to conflicts and emergencies\, people are unable to register vital events or obtain proof of identity and civil status. Without this proof\, they are unable to access critical social services such as health\, education\, and social welfare. 

This can have catastrophic consequences for women and children\, who are especially vulnerable to gender-based and sexual violence in situations of conflict and fragility\, and who are the first victims of conflict. Without proof of civil status or legal identity\, they are even more vulnerable because they are unable to access the social services they need\, nor can they prove links to their countries of origin. Proving these links is key in order to return to their countries of origin or to be relocated to another safe country by mandated United Nations agencies.

This project is supported under the Centre of Excellence for Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (CRVS) Systems\, a joint initiative of IDRC and Global Affairs Canada. With the collaboration of Addis Ababa University\, the project will assess the existing legal and policy environment related to CRVS and examine the effect of civil registration status on the vulnerability of women and children displaced due to ethnic conflicts in Ethiopia. This study will examine the impact of the lack of documentation on access to humanitarian and other essential services\, as well as vulnerability to sexual abuse\, food insecurity\, poor health\, school dropouts\, and conflict with the host population over resources. 

Previous studies on the subject have either examined the importance of identity documentation or the vulnerability of internally displaced populations\, but few have considered the link between access to identity documentation and vulnerability. This will\, therefore\, be an important contribution to the field. Expected outputs include a peer-reviewed publication and a high-level synthesis report that will be presented to the Civil Registration Technical Advisory Group to propose legislative modifications for internally displaced population-facilitated registration.,Les situations d’urgence et les déplacements de populations présentent d’importants défis pour la prestation de services efficaces d’enregistrement des faits d’état civil\, tels que les mariages\, les naissances et les décès. Lorsque les systèmes d’enregistrement de l’état civil échouent en raison de conflits et de situations d’urgence\, les personnes sont incapables d’enregistrer les faits d’état civil ou d’obtenir une preuve d’identité et d’état civil. Sans cette preuve\, les personnes sont incapables d’accéder aux services sociaux essentiels comme la santé\, l’éducation et le bien-être social. 

Cela peut avoir des conséquences catastrophiques pour les femmes et les enfants\, qui sont particulièrement vulnérables à la violence sexuelle et sexospécifique en situation de conflit et de fragilité\, et qui sont les premières victimes de conflits. Sans preuve d’état civil ou d’identité juridique\, ces personnes sont encore plus vulnérables car elles ne sont pas en mesure d’accéder aux services sociaux dont elles ont besoin\, ni de prouver leurs liens avec leur pays d’origine. Il est essentiel que ces personnes prouvent ces liens afin de retourner dans leur pays d’origine ou d’être réinstallées dans un autre pays sûr par les organismes habilités des Nations Unies.

Ce projet est appuyé par le Centre d’excellence sur les systèmes d’enregistrement et de statistiques de l’état civil (ESEC)\, une initiative conjointe du CRDI et d’Affaires mondiales Canada. Avec la collaboration de l’Université d’Addis-Abeba\, le projet évaluera le contexte juridique et politique existant qui est lié aux systèmes d’ESEC et examinera les effets de l’enregistrement de l’état civil sur la vulnérabilité des femmes et des enfants qui sont déplacés en raison de conflits ethniques en Éthiopie. De plus\, cette étude examinera les conséquences du manque de documentation sur l’accès aux services humanitaires et à d’autres services essentiels\, ainsi que la vulnérabilité aux abus sexuels\, à l’insécurité alimentaire\, à la mauvaise santé\, au décrochage scolaire\, ainsi qu’aux conflits avec la population d’accueil au sujet des ressources. 

Les études antérieures sur le sujet ont examiné l’importance des documents d’identité ou la vulnérabilité des personnes déplacées à l’intérieur de leur pays\, mais peu d’entre elles ont examiné le lien entre l’accès aux documents d’identité et la vulnérabilité. Par conséquent\, la présente étude sera une importante contribution dans le domaine.
